Job.JobDescription:
CLOVIS UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT POSITION DESCRIPTION
Position: Classroom Teacher FLSA: Exempt Reports To: Site Principal Pay Grade: Certificated Salary Schedule
SUMMARY
Requirements / Qualifications Must possess or be eligible for appropriate California public school teaching credential. If applicant is not in possession of a current, valid credential, a Plan to Complete form must be attached with this application. A link to the Plan to Complete can be found on the right hand side of this posting.
All other applicants interested in the position must, electronically, complete and attach the following:
- Current online Edjoin application - Philosophy of Education Statement - Three (3) Letters of Recommendation dated within 18 months of application - Current Resume - Copy of Valid California Public School Credentials - Copy of CTC Certificate of Clearance (COC) - Copy of Transcripts (Unofficial Accepted for Application Purposes) - Copy of RICA (if multiple subject or Special Education) - Copy of MSAT, CSET, SSAT, OR PRAXIS OR other documentation of Subject Matter Competence - English Learner Authorization (CLAD, or authorization embedded in credential)
**NOTE: CELL PHONE-PHOTO COPIES OF DOCUMENTS ARE NOT ACCEPTED**
Comments and Other Information This school district does not discriminate on the basis of race, color, national origin, age, religion, political affiliation, gender, mental or physical disability, sex orientation, or any other basis protected by federal, state or local law, ordinance or regulation, in its educational program(s) or employment. No person shall be denied employment solely because of any impairment which is unrelated to the ability to engage in activities involved in the position(s) or program for which application has been made.

Job.JobTitle: Coach - Girls Flag Football Head Coach (Stipend Position) - Del Norte High School
Job.JobDescription:
Job Summary The Poway Unified School District is seeking applications for the fall season 2026 for a Girls Flag Football Head Coaching position at Del Norte High School.
About Us: Del Norte High School is committed to fostering a culture of excellence in athletics and academics. Our flag football program is dedicated to developing student-athletes not only in their athletic abilities but also in teamwork, sportsmanship, and personal growth. We are looking for a passionate and experienced Head Coach to lead our team.
Position Overview: The Head Coach will be responsible for the overall management of the flag football program. This includes developing training plans, coaching during practices and meets, and promoting a positive team environment. The ideal candidate will have a strong background in flag football, coaching experience, and a commitment to student-athlete development.
Key Responsibilities: • Design and implement training programs. • Lead daily practices and coach at games. • Foster a positive, inclusive, and competitive team culture. • Communicate effectively with athletes, parents, and school administration. • Monitor and promote the academic and personal growth of student-athletes. • Organize and oversee team events, fundraising, and community service initiatives. • Ensure compliance with all school and league policies. • Manage all program administrative requirements.
Requirements / Qualifications Qualifications: • Previous coaching experience at the high school or club level is preferred. • Strong knowledge of techniques, rules, and competitive strategies. • Excellent leadership, communication, and interpersonal skills. • Ability to motivate and inspire student-athletes. • CPR/AED/First Aid certification is required • Must pass background checks as required by the school district.
How to Apply: Interested candidates should submit a resume, cover letter, and references to Matt Brammer, Athletic Director, at mbrammer@powayusd.com
Comments and Other Information The Poway Unified School District (PUSD) is an equal opportunity employer/program and is committed to an active Nondiscrimination Program. PUSD prohibits discrimination, harassment, intimidation, and bullying based on actual or perceived protected characteristics under the law, including but not limited to ancestry, age, color, disability, gender, gender identity, gender expression, nationality, race or ethnicity, immigration status, religion, sex, sexual orientation, or association with a person or a group with one or more of these actual or perceived characteristics. For more information, please contact the Title IX/Equity Compliance Officer, Associate Superintendent of Personnel Support Services, Poway Unified School District, 15250 Avenue of Science, San Diego, CA 92128-3406, 858-521-2800, extension 2121.
Job.SalaryRange: $4157 - $5041 (depending on experience; stipend paid over 3 months)

Job.JobTitle: Athletic Coach - Coed Cheerleader Sponsor Coach: McClymonds (Winter 2025)
Job.JobDescription:
The Athletic Coach - Coed Cheerleader Sponsor Coach: McClymonds role at McClymonds emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Athletic Coach - Coed Cheerleader Sponsor Coach: McClymonds coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At McClymonds, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Athletic Coach - Coed Cheerleader Sponsor Coach: McClymonds reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent McClymonds at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Athletic Coach - Coed Cheerleader Sponsor Coach: McClymonds may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Athletic Coach - Coed Cheerleader Sponsor Coach: McClymonds monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Athletic Coach - Coed Cheerleader Sponsor Coach: McClymonds must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at McClymonds.
Job.CompanyDescription: Oakland Unified School District coaching jobs

Job.JobTitle: Athletic Coach - Girls Basketball Coach: McClymonds:(Winter 2025)
Job.JobDescription:
The Athletic Coach - Girls Basketball Coach: McClymonds at McClymonds is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Athletic Coach - Girls Basketball Coach: McClymonds plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at McClymonds reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Athletic Coach - Girls Basketball Coach: McClymonds expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Athletic Coach - Girls Basketball Coach: McClymonds supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Athletic Coach - Girls Basketball Coach: McClymonds may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at McClymonds. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.
Job.CompanyDescription: Oakland Unified School District coaching jobs

Job.JobTitle: Athletic Coach - Coed Cheerleader Sponsor Coach: Fremont (Winter 2025)
Job.JobDescription:
The Athletic Coach - Coed Cheerleader Sponsor Coach: Fremont at Fremont is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Athletic Coach - Coed Cheerleader Sponsor Coach: Fremont is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Fremont, the Athletic Coach - Coed Cheerleader Sponsor Coach: Fremont helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Athletic Coach - Coed Cheerleader Sponsor Coach: Fremont may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Fremont well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Athletic Coach - Coed Cheerleader Sponsor Coach: Fremont follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobTitle: Athletic Coach - Girls Soccer Coach: Fremont (Winter 2025)
Job.JobDescription:
The Athletic Coach - Girls Soccer Coach: Fremont role at Fremont is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Athletic Coach - Girls Soccer Coach: Fremont is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Fremont, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Athletic Coach - Girls Soccer Coach: Fremont sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Fremont, the Athletic Coach - Girls Soccer Coach: Fremont is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Athletic Coach - Girls Soccer Coach: Fremont at Fremont is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobTitle: Athletic Coach - Girls Basketball Coach: Life Academy (Winter 2025)
Job.JobDescription:
The Athletic Coach - Girls Basketball Coach: Life Academy at Life Academy is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Athletic Coach - Girls Basketball Coach: Life Academy manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Life Academy, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Athletic Coach - Girls Basketball Coach: Life Academy demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Athletic Coach - Girls Basketball Coach: Life Academy follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Athletic Coach - Girls Basketball Coach: Life Academy at Life Academy allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job.JobTitle: Athletic Coach - Girls Soccer Coach: Fremont (Winter 2025)
Job.JobDescription:
The Athletic Coach - Girls Soccer Coach: Fremont at Fremont is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Athletic Coach - Girls Soccer Coach: Fremont are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Fremont use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Athletic Coach - Girls Soccer Coach: Fremont recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Athletic Coach - Girls Soccer Coach: Fremont collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Athletic Coach - Girls Soccer Coach: Fremont maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Fremont. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: Athletic Coach - Girls Soccer Coach: Life Academy (Winter 2025)
Job.JobDescription:
The Athletic Coach - Girls Soccer Coach: Life Academy role at Life Academy is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Athletic Coach - Girls Soccer Coach: Life Academy is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Life Academy are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Athletic Coach - Girls Soccer Coach: Life Academy listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Athletic Coach - Girls Soccer Coach: Life Academy encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Athletic Coach - Girls Soccer Coach: Life Academy follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Life Academy, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Athletic Coach - Girls Soccer Coach: Life Academy at Life Academy, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: Athletic Coach - Boys Basketball Coach: Life Academy (Winter 2025)
Job.JobDescription:
The Athletic Coach - Boys Basketball Coach: Life Academy position at Life Academy is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Athletic Coach - Boys Basketball Coach: Life Academy is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Life Academy, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Athletic Coach - Boys Basketball Coach: Life Academy encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Athletic Coach - Boys Basketball Coach: Life Academy also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Athletic Coach - Boys Basketball Coach: Life Academy role at Life Academy is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobTitle: Northgate Varsity Girls Water Polo Coach #3818
Job.JobDescription:
The Northgate Varsity Girls Water Polo Coach #3818 at Northgate High is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Northgate Varsity Girls Water Polo Coach #3818 is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Northgate High, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Northgate Varsity Girls Water Polo Coach #3818 helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Northgate Varsity Girls Water Polo Coach #3818 works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Northgate High operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Northgate High with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Northgate Varsity Girls Water Polo Coach #3818 reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Northgate Varsity Girls Water Polo Coach #3818 role at Northgate High.

Job.JobTitle: #189-26, Head Coach, Basketball , Sequoia High School, 2025-26
Job.JobDescription:
About the Employer Nestled close to the majestic Sierra mountains in the heart of California's San Joaquin Valley, the Visalia Unified School District is committed to providing students young and old with the tools and skills necessary to succeed in life.
Established in 1885, VUSD is the oldest school district in Tulare County. Our services span 214 square miles with a population base of over 135,000. Our family of schools includes 26 elementary schools, a newcomer language center, five middle schools, four comprehensive high schools, a continuation high school, an adult school,a charter independent study school, a K-8 charter home school, and a charter technical early college high school. Over 32,000 students Pre-K to adult are served through Visalia Unified School District.
Our outstanding workforce is comprised of over 3,000 certificated and classified staff. They make our district the jewel of the Central Valley.
Requirements / Qualifications - California Teaching or Pupil Personnel Services Credential, preferred - First Aid, CPR, Concussion, Sudden Cardiac Arrest - Fundamentals of Coaching Certificate - Water Safety Certification, if applicable - Valid California Driver's License and maintain insurability
INCOMPLETE APPLICATIONS WILL NOT BE CONSIDERED. ALL APPLICATION MATERIALS MUST BE SUBMITTED THROUGH EDJOIN AND MUST INCLUDE: * Answers to Supplemental Questions (Valid NFHS Coach License (Fundamentals of Coaching only)) * Certificate Copy (Valid First Aid Certification (Online is not accepted)) * Certification (Valid Heat Illness Prevention Certification (nfhslearn.com)) * CPR/First Aid Certification (Valid CPR Certification (Online is not accepted, please contact 559-730-7512 if you need CPR certification)) * Health (Valid Concussion Training Certification (nfhslearn.com)) * Other (Valid Sudden Cardiac Arrest Certification (nfhslearn.com))
Comments and Other Information Visalia Unified School District is dedicated to the goal of building a culturally diverse faculty and staff. Qualified candidates who represent diverse racial, ethnic and cultural backgrounds are encouraged to apply.
Statement of Non-Discrimination/Harassment (Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973): The district prohibits discrimination, harassment, intimidation, and bullying in all district educational programs, activities, or employment on the basis and/or association with a person or group with one or more of these actual or perceived characteristics of age, ancestry, color, disability, gender, gender identity, gender expression, nationality, race or ethnicity, religion, sex, sexual orientation, parental, pregnancy, family or marital status.
A copy of the districts Uniform Complaint/Sexual Harassment Policies can be found at: www.visalia.k12.ca.us/boardpolicies/BP1312-3.pdf A copy of the sexual harassment policies for students and employees can be found at: http://www.visalia.k12.ca.us/boardpolicies/BP5145-7.PDF (students) http://www.visalia.k12.ca.us/boardpolicies/BP4119-11.pdf (employees)
For any questions concerning Title II, Title V, Title IX, or Section 504 please contact the following compliance officers:
VUSD Compliance Officers 5000 West Cypress Avenue Visalia, CA 93277 (559) 730-7300
Assistant Superintendent, Instructional Services (Special Education, Adult Basic Education, Consolidated Categorical Aid Programs, Migrant Education, Career Technical Education) Assistant Superintendent, Administrative Services (Child Nutrition Programs) Assistant Superintendent, Human Resources (Personnel) Director, Student Services (District 504 Coordinator)

Job.JobTitle: Coach - GOHS Boys Volleyball Assistant Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Coach - GOHS Boys Volleyball Assistant Coach at Anthony Califano is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Coach - GOHS Boys Volleyball Assistant Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Anthony Califano reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Coach - GOHS Boys Volleyball Assistant Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Coach - GOHS Boys Volleyball Assistant Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Coach - GOHS Boys Volleyball Assistant Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Anthony Califano. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.
Job.Location: Temecula Valley Unified School District, Temecula
Job.SalaryRange: Stipend Per Season, Pay dependent on experience

Job.JobTitle: Coach - GOHS Assistant Girls Basketball Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Coach - GOHS Assistant Girls Basketball Coach position at Anthony Califano provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Coach - GOHS Assistant Girls Basketball Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Anthony Califano, the Coach - GOHS Assistant Girls Basketball Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Coach - GOHS Assistant Girls Basketball Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Coach - GOHS Assistant Girls Basketball Coach at Anthony Califano is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.
Job.SalaryRange: Pay dependent on experience, Stipend Per Season

Job.JobTitle: COACH - WATER POLO 2025/2026 SEASON (Various Sites) - JP #8
Job.JobDescription:
The COACH - WATER POLO 2025/2026 SEASON (Various Sites) - JP #8 role at Rialto Unified School District is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the COACH - WATER POLO 2025/2026 SEASON (Various Sites) - JP #8 is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Rialto Unified School District are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The COACH - WATER POLO 2025/2026 SEASON (Various Sites) - JP #8 listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the COACH - WATER POLO 2025/2026 SEASON (Various Sites) - JP #8 encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The COACH - WATER POLO 2025/2026 SEASON (Various Sites) - JP #8 follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Rialto Unified School District, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the COACH - WATER POLO 2025/2026 SEASON (Various Sites) - JP #8 at Rialto Unified School District, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.
Job.CompanyDescription: Rialto Unified School District coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The COACH - TENNIS 2025/2026 SEASON (Various Sites) - JP #7 at Rialto Unified School District is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the COACH - TENNIS 2025/2026 SEASON (Various Sites) - JP #7 are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Rialto Unified School District use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The COACH - TENNIS 2025/2026 SEASON (Various Sites) - JP #7 recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the COACH - TENNIS 2025/2026 SEASON (Various Sites) - JP #7 collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The COACH - TENNIS 2025/2026 SEASON (Various Sites) - JP #7 maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Rialto Unified School District. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: Boys Volleyball Head Coach - El Toro High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Boys Volleyball Head Coach - El Toro High School role at Lisette Nunez is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Boys Volleyball Head Coach - El Toro High School is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Lisette Nunez, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Boys Volleyball Head Coach - El Toro High School sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Lisette Nunez, the Boys Volleyball Head Coach - El Toro High School is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Boys Volleyball Head Coach - El Toro High School at Lisette Nunez is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.
Job.CompanyDescription: Saddleback Valley Unified Sch. D. coaching jobs

Job.JobTitle: MMHS - Coach - Girl's Softball - Volunteer Assistant Coach - Level TBD - Open & Promotional Murrieta Valley Unified School District
Job.JobDescription:
About the Employer Welcome rookies who need training and support and have various pathways to help you grow. Our Human Resources team will work with you to help you get to where you want to go!
Thank you for your interest in joining MVUSD, a student-centered district of choice in south Riverside County. We proudly educate over 23,000 students from transitional kindergarten through high school with rigorous academic programs designed to help every student succeed.
We inspire students to participate in our highly acclaimed visual and performing arts programs, championship athletic programs and nationally recognized student activity programs.
Highly qualified teachers and staff provide a world-class education that integrates academic and vocational skills and prepares students for the challenges and opportunities of a competitive global society. The district also offers adult and community education, early childhood education, child care and a parent center.
MVUSD strives to recruit and retain the very best candidates who will inspire every student to think, to learn, to achieve, to care.

Job.JobTitle: VMHS - Track & Field - Distance - Assistant Varsity Coach- Open & Promotional - *Murrieta Valley Unified School District
Job.JobDescription:
The VMHS - Track & Field - Distance - Assistant Varsity Coach- Open & Promotional - *Murrieta Valley Unified School District position at David Smola is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the VMHS - Track & Field - Distance - Assistant Varsity Coach- Open & Promotional - *Murrieta Valley Unified School District works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The VMHS - Track & Field - Distance - Assistant Varsity Coach- Open & Promotional - *Murrieta Valley Unified School District at David Smola sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At David Smola, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The VMHS - Track & Field - Distance - Assistant Varsity Coach- Open & Promotional - *Murrieta Valley Unified School District encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The VMHS - Track & Field - Distance - Assistant Varsity Coach- Open & Promotional - *Murrieta Valley Unified School District is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the VMHS - Track & Field - Distance - Assistant Varsity Coach- Open & Promotional - *Murrieta Valley Unified School District position at David Smola is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.JobTitle: Head Coach - Varsity Girls Flag Football
Job.JobDescription:
The Head Coach - Varsity Girls Flag Football role at Vista del Lago High School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Head Coach - Varsity Girls Flag Football is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Vista del Lago High School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Head Coach - Varsity Girls Flag Football listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Head Coach - Varsity Girls Flag Football encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Head Coach - Varsity Girls Flag Football follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Vista del Lago High School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Head Coach - Varsity Girls Flag Football at Vista del Lago High School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: VARIOUS COACHING POSITIONS - Various Sites - Eligibility Pool - 2025-26 School Year
Job.JobDescription:
IN-HOUSE VACANCY - INTERNAL CANDIDATES ONLY This position is only available to current employees of this school district. Applications submitted by job seekers not currently employed by the school district will not be considered.
About the Employer The Pomona Unified School District, in partnership with parents and community, provides a well-rounded, challenging, and quality educational program that develops character and integrity. Students are equipped and empowered through academic opportunities, career and technical experiences, and whole-student supports needed for college and career success. A service culture of operational excellence, collaboration, and continuous improvement empowers all to flourish with trust and pride.
Requirements / Qualifications **Non-certificated applicants may apply under the California Administrative Code Section 5531.
Prospective walk-on coaches whether paid or unpaid are required to fill out a detailed online application and list positive references that confirm qualifications and recent successful work and coaching experiences.
Please refer to the Job Description link above for further details.
Please ensure that all the following documents are attached to your application upon submission. Certificate Copy (Valid NFHS Heat Illness Prevention Training Certificate) Certification (Valid NFHS Fundamental of Coaching Training Certificate, if returning as a High School coach.) CPR/First Aid Certification (Valid certificates approved by the American Red Cross or American Heart Association are accepted; on-line training courses are not accepted.) Health (Valid NFHS Concussion In Sports Training Certificate) Resume (Current resume.) Test Results/Materials (Valid NFHS Sudden Cardiac Arrest Training Certificate)
Comments and Other Information If you submitted an application under the direction of a school site Principal, Athletic Director or Activities Director, please contact Human Resources at (909)397-4800, ext. 23800 for an update on the status of your application and recruitment. A Coach/advisor shall not begin rendering any services in either a paid or non-paid District position, (coach, advisor, other support work, etc.), nor have any contact with any students nor participate as an advisor or coach in any meetings, practices, workouts, or contests until coach/advisor has been completely cleared to do so and informed of such clearance by Human Resources.
New hire paperwork, background checks and employment clearances for new hires, rehires and volunteers are coordinated and distributed by the district's Human Resources office during the recruitment process.
The provisions of this announcement do not constitute an expressed or implied contract, and any provisions contained in this announcement may be modified or revoked without notice. Employment is contingent upon fingerprint clearance from the Department of Justice. Fingerprints will be taken at the time the position is accepted. There is a fee of $63.00 for fingerprinting. Payment is due at the time of service in the form of a money order, cashier's check or cash – PERSONAL CHECKS NOT ACCEPTED.
Non-Discrimination Policy The Pomona Unified School District does not discriminate based on actual or perceived characteristics such as age, ancestry, color, ethnic group identification, gender expression, gender identity, gender, genetic information, mental or physical disability, nationality, national origin, race, ethnicity, religion, sex, or sexual orientation, or on the basis or a person's association with a person or group with one or more of these actual or perceived characteristics in any program or activity.
If you believe you have been subjected to discrimination, harassment, intimidation, or bullying, you should immediately contact the school site principal and/or Assistant Superintendent, Human Resources (CCR Title 5 and Title IX Officer), Silvia San Martin, at 909-397-4800, ext. 23800 or silvia.sanmartin@pusd.org. A copy of PUSD's Uniform Complaint Policy and PUSD's Non-Discrimination Policy are available upon request.
Mandated Reporter Certificate of Completion of the School Personnel Mandated Reporter Training: https://www.mandatedreporterca.com/training/school-personnel Please be advised that, effective October 1, 2024, the California Department of Social Services (CDSS) has begun charging a fee of $7.99 for the interoperable training certificate for the School Personnel Mandated Reporter Training. Payment for the certificate is no longer optional.

DOCUMENTS REQUIRED Applicants are required to submit the following through Ed-Join prior to the position closing date/time: • Edjoin application • Letter of interest • Three (3) current professional letters of reference that relates to the coach position • Resume of experience EDUCATION/EXPERIENCE: Minimum two (2) years successful (recent) experience at the varsity wrestling level (within last five (5) years); Experience working directly with collegiate and/or public school districts is highly desirable; Bachelor's degree preferred; Master's Degree desirable; Experience as a certificated staff member desirable; Must have demonstrated ability to lead and direct a sports program, working knowledge of CIF rules/regulations, effective oral and written communication, and strong organizational skills Comments and Other Information All materials must be submitted through Edjoin. AB2534 As of January 1, 2025, in accordance with Education Code section 44939.5, jobseekers applying for Certificated positions are required by law to provide a complete list of every school district, county office of education, charter school and/or state special school they have previously been employed by, no matter the length of service. This includes any part-time and/or substitution work in addition to any full-time employment positions. Jobseekers applying for this position must complete the AB2534 section of the EdJoin application. Failure to disclose any previous educational employment may result in the disqualification of your application and/or may be deemed dishonesty in the hiring process and subject to discharge should you become employed. PLEASE DO NOT LIST INDIVIDUAL SCHOOL SITES, ONLY LIST THE PUBLIC EMPLOYING AGENCY (I.E. DISTRICT OR COUNTY OFFICE OF ED. OR CHARTER SCHOOL OR STATE SPECIAL SCHOOL).

About the Employer The ABC Unified School District is known throughout the State of California as a leader in educational planning and innovation. The District has received county, state, and national recognition for outstanding programs in counseling, alternative education, staff development, and labor relations.
Staff members have been selected to participate on state and national educational committees and have been invited to make presentations at national, state, and local conferences. Students have been recognized as National Merit scholars, academic decathlon winners, and participants in the Model United Nations program. Approximately 85 percent of the graduating students go on to higher education.
The ABC Unified School District includes nineteen elementary schools, five middle schools, three comprehensive high schools, a college prep 7-12 school, a continuation high school, infant/children centers, extended-day care, and adult school.
Job Summary ATHLETIC TRAINER - PROFESSIONAL EXPERT ABC Unified School District High Schools Temporary Assignment (25-26 School Year) No Health Benefits/No Holidays
ESSENTIAL DUTIES: Under the general supervision of the school’s principal and athletic director, provide comprehensive athletic training services to student-athletes by assessing and treating sports-related injuries; implementing injury prevention programs; coordinating with coaches and medical professionals; maintaining accurate medical records; and educating student-athletes on proper training techniques and injury prevention. Monitor and manage the athletic training facility, including equipment and supplies. Attend athletic events and practices as required to provide immediate care for injured athletes. Assume such other duties as the principal or the district may assign
QUALIFICATIONS: College-level course work in physical education, athletic training or a related field and one one year of experience involving the care, management and prevention of athletic injuries.
Current Athletic Trainer Certification (ATC) from the Board of Certification (BOC) required.
Current CPR and First Aid certifications.
Experience working with secondary school athletes preferred.
Requirements / Qualifications Current Athletic Trainer Certification (ATC) from the Board of Certification (BOC) required.
Current CPR and First Aid certifications.
Resume and 1 letter of recommendation.
SELECTION PROCEDURE: The selection procedure may consist of any or all of the following: training and experience evaluation, technical oral interview and general qualifications appraisal interview.
Job.Location: ABC Unified School District High Schools
Job.Experience: one year
Job.Benefits: No Health Benefits/No Holidays
Job.CompanyDescription: ABC Unified School District coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Athletic Coach at Compton Unified School District is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Assistant Athletic Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Compton Unified School District, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Assistant Athletic Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Assistant Athletic Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Compton Unified School District operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Compton Unified School District with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Assistant Athletic Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Assistant Athletic Coach role at Compton Unified School District.
Job.CompanyDescription: Compton Unified School District coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The VOLLEYBALL HEAD COACH at Unidos Middle School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the VOLLEYBALL HEAD COACH are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Unidos Middle School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The VOLLEYBALL HEAD COACH recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the VOLLEYBALL HEAD COACH collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The VOLLEYBALL HEAD COACH maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Unidos Middle School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Associate Athletics Director, Intercollegiate Athletics (0213U) #80841
Job.JobDescription:
The Chief Financial Officer & Senior Associate Athletics Director, Intercollegiate Athletics #80841 role at University of California - Berkeley is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Chief Financial Officer & Senior Associate Athletics Director, Intercollegiate Athletics #80841 is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at University of California - Berkeley are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Chief Financial Officer & Senior Associate Athletics Director, Intercollegiate Athletics #80841 listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Chief Financial Officer & Senior Associate Athletics Director, Intercollegiate Athletics #80841 encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Chief Financial Officer & Senior Associate Athletics Director, Intercollegiate Athletics #80841 follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At University of California - Berkeley, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Chief Financial Officer & Senior Associate Athletics Director, Intercollegiate Athletics #80841 at University of California - Berkeley, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.
Job.CompanyDescription: University of California - Berkeley coaching jobs

Job.JobTitle: Sport Clubs Coach II - Women's Soccer Club (AS)
Job.JobDescription:
Job Description The Sport Clubs Coach II (Women's Soccer) is responsible for the coaching of the assigned Women's Soccer club(s).
Duties General: Responsible for coordinating practices; home and away competitions; and tournaments. Must be able to teach a wide array of participants from beginners to experienced high school and collegiate athletes. Properly instruct fundamentals and technique. Administrative: The coach will assist club leadership with short and long-term goals and a plan of action for the academic year. Other: Performs other duties as assigned to support the department, division, and university.
Additional Knowledge, Skills, and Experience : (Note any additional knowledge, skills, experience, and education, that are required or that you think are important for this position.) Requirements: Candidates must have, as a minimum: two years experience coaching at the youth, high school, junior college or collegiate club level and be a High School Graduate/GED Preferred: Bachelor's Degree Two years' experience coaching at the youth, high school, junior college or collegiate club level and be a High School Graduate/GED. Candidates need to effectively communicate with a diverse student population, have demonstrated leadership skills, organizational skills and experience commensurate with coaching at the collegiate club level
Pay & Work Schedule Hourly wage is commensurate with knowledge, skills and experience. This is a seasonal, hourly, part time position typically from August through May of the following year. Travel is required for tournaments. Practices are typically 2-3 days per week September through April, with 3-5 tournaments during the season mainly in Southern California; though some out of state travel will be required. Typical schedule will be 8-20 hours weekly when classes are in session. Expected hiring range: $20.00 - $30.00 per hour
General Information This position is a sensitive position as designated by the CSU and Associated Students. A background check (including a criminal records check) must be completed satisfactorily. Failure to satisfactorily complete the background check may affect the application status of applicants or continued employment of current Associated Students employees who apply for the position. Candidates should apply by completing the on-line application. To submit an application and for more detailed information on the application and hiring process, please visit this link: www.csun.edu/careers
ABOUT ASSOCIATED STUDENTS The CSUN Associated Students is a 501(c)3 corporation integrated with California State University, Northridge. Its mission is to serve as the primary advocate for students at CSUN and to provide excellent, meaningful programs and services designed to create and enhance a spirited, learning-focused campus environment. The AS offers programs in sustainability and recycling; outdoor adventures; sport clubs; child care; ticket, transportation passes and attraction discount ticket sales; concerts, fairs and lectures. Its own infrastructure also includes risk management; information technology support; marketing; accounting and human resources.
