Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the YCHS JV Head Softball coach at Yuba City Unified School Dist. allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job.JobDescription:
The YCHS Assistant Track Coach at Yuba City High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the YCHS Assistant Track Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Yuba City High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The YCHS Assistant Track Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the YCHS Assistant Track Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the YCHS Assistant Track Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Yuba City High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobDescription: QUALIFICATIONS: Previous high school golf coaching experience desired Knowledge of golf rules and regulations Ability to work with high school students Ability to work cooperatively with parents, administration, and staff Demonstrate organizational skills Valid First Aid/CPR cards All coaches are required to be fingerprinted and cleared by the Department of Justice prior to working with students, as well as obtain a TB clearance. All coaches are required to complete the three ASEP/NFHS coaching certification courses prior to coaching; 1) Fundamentals of Coaching, 2) Sudden Cardiac Arrest, 3) Concussion in Sports-What you need to know, prior to working with students. All coaches are required to complete Heat Illness Prevention prior to working with students. All coaches are required to complete Mandated Reporter Training prior to working with students.

Job.JobTitle: YCHS Boys basketball Varsity Assistant Head coach
Job.JobDescription: QUALIFICATIONS: 1. Has the ability to organize and supervise a total sports program. 2. Has previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport. (Major sports) 3. The head coach must have substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and, at the same time, must continue to examine new theories and procedures pertinent to the field. 4. The head coach must serve as an appropriate role model for student athletes through his/her instructions and actions. REPORTS TO: The athletic director, who provides overall objectives and final evaluation in conjunction with the high school principal. SUPERVISES: In several instances, the head coach must advise, coordinate and support a staff of high school assistant coaches and middle school coaches in conjunction with the athletic director and respective principal. JOB GOAL: To instruct athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the coach must instruct and demonstrate behaviors that lead to socially acceptable character development, self discipline, self confidence, and pride of accomplishment in the student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc. GENERAL: 1. The success of athletic programs has a strong influence on the community’s image of the entire system. The public exposure is a considerable responsibility and community/parent pressure for winning performance is taxing, but must not override the objectives of good sportsmanship and good mental health. 2. The position includes other unusual aspect such as extended time, risk injury factor and due process predicaments. 3. It is the express intent of this job description to give sufficient guidance to function. In cases not specifically covered, it shall be assumed that a coach shall exercise common sense and good judgment. DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: 1. Has a thorough knowledge of all the athletic policies approved by the Plainwell Community Schools’ Board of Education and is responsible for their implementation by the entire staff of the sports program. 2. Has knowledge of existing system, state and league regulations; implements same consistently and interprets them for staff. 3. Understands the proper administrative line of command and refers all requests or grievances through proper channels. Is aware of all public/staff/departmental meetings that require attendance. STAFF RESPONSIBILITIES: 4. Established the fundamental philosophy, skills and techniques to be taught by staff. Designs conferences, clinics and staff meetings to insure staff awareness of overall program. 5. Trains and informs staff, encourages professional growth by encouraging clinic attendance according to local clinic policy. 6. Delegates specific duties, supervises implementation and, at season’s end, analyzes staff

Job.JobDescription:
About the Employer Founded in 1923 and located in the heart of Silicon Valley, the Fremont Union High School District is consistently recognized as one of the most respected and highest performing high school districts in California. Our five comprehensive high schools - Cupertino, Fremont, Homestead, Lynbrook, and Monta Vista, as well as our Adult School - have garnered many honors and accolades based on the outstanding achievement of our students and District programs designed to support their success. Beyond academics, students in our five schools participate in a wide range of activities, including leadership, athletics, speech and debate, Future Business Leaders of America, student publications and the visual and performing arts. We are proud of the incredible diversity that exists within our District, with more than 60 different languages represented across our student population. The richness of this diversity is one of our greatest assets, offering many opportunities to emphasize the critical importance of inclusion and for our staff and students to learn from the unique experiences of others.
Requirements / Qualifications - High School Diploma - Once hired, coaches must have fingerprint clearance, a current (negative) TB test, CPR, First Aid, Basic Water Safety, and complete four online coach courses with the National ASEP registry ("Fundamentals of Coaching," "Sudden Cardiac Arrest," and "Concussion Certification" and "Heat Illness Prevention") along with various Keenan training modules as required. Please do not mail, e-mail, or fax documents to our office. Application and all accompanied/required documents must be attached via EdJoin. Job.JobTitle: Football - Head Men's JV Coach - Encinal High (EXTERNAL APPLICANTS) - 2026/27 SY - REOPENED
Job.JobDescription: About the Employer The Alameda Unified School District is committed to upholding our community's core values of equity and excellence for every student by providing inclusive and safe conditions for learning that challenge and support every student to be culturally competent and prepared for college, career, and community participation. Our vision is that each and every child is compassionate, confident, and feels successful, academically prepared, and able to make meaningful, positive impact in their lives, the lives of others, and the world around them. We are a diverse community of seventeen (17) schools serving approximately 9000 students ranging from Preschool to Adult Learners. Our students represent many cultures and ethnic groups, with 72 languages spoken by students. Approximately 14% of our students are English Language Learners; 12% receive Special Education Services; and 29% are Socioeconomically Disadvantaged. Our student population is comprised of 7% African American, 27% Asian, 16% Hispanic, 30% White, and 12% Two or more races. Equity Imperative The Alameda Unified School District believes that inequities exist within our current educational system. Our African American and Latinx students are underserved and it is our responsibility at Alameda Unified School District to provide equitable educational opportunities for them and all students. A diverse workforce is and is beneficial to all of our students. With this ideal in mind, our goal is to find the best candidates suited to uphold our community's core values of equity and excellence for every student. For more information about the Alameda Unified School District, please visit: https://www.alamedaunified.org Job Summary Three (3) years coaching experience directly related to the duties and responsibilities specified below. * Teach the fundamental skills and drills of the game of football. * Instruct players in the rules, regulations, equipment, of the sport. * Models sports-like behavior and maintains appropriate conduct towards players, officials, spectators, and families. * Willingness to work in a group coaching environment. * Provide academic advising to each player. * Track the academic progress of each student/athlete. * Work collaboratively with Athletic Director, Administration, Teachers, and Parents. * Ability and willingness to fund-raise for the program. * Perform all other duties as assigned by the Athletic Director. Requirements / Qualifications CPR/First Aid through American Red Cross or American Heart Association NFHS Certificates: Fundamentals, Concussion, Sudden Cardiac Arrest, Heat Illness Prevention, and Covid 19 for Coaches and Administrators Valid California Driver's License Need not hold a credential
Job.Experience: Three (3) years coaching experience
Job.SalaryRange: Pay dependent on experience, Stipend - TBD

Job.district: San Luis Coastal Unified Sch. Dist.
Job.JobDescription:
The Coach - Softball - SLHS role at Adam Basch emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Coach - Softball - SLHS coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Adam Basch, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Coach - Softball - SLHS reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Adam Basch at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Coach - Softball - SLHS may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Coach - Softball - SLHS monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Coach - Softball - SLHS must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Adam Basch.
Job.Experience: High School level preferred
Job.CompanyDescription: San Luis Coastal Unified Sch. Dist. coaching jobs
Job.CompanyName: San Luis Coastal Unified Sch. Dist.

Job.JobTitle: Coach (Head)-Track & Field JV Girls - Novato High School Spring 2025-2026
Job.JobDescription:
About the Employer: Novato Unified School District (NUSD) has approximately 800 staff members who, along with the larger school community, are responsible for the education of 7,400 students. We have eight elementary schools, including one dual-language immersion, one TK-8 school, two middle schools, and two comprehensive high schools. NUSD also has an Alternative Education Center housing a continuation school and an independent study student program serving grades K-12. All schools within Novato Unified offer special education services, along with Gifted and Talented Education (GATE), and special assistance is provided for all English learner students.
OUR MISSION: Engage, inspire and empower all students, in a rapidly changing world, to realize their life goals.
OUR VISION: NUSD will provide an innovative and personalized learning experience for every student in a caring and supportive environment to develop the knowledge and skills necessary to be successful and productive citizens. NUSD will engage parents, teachers, and our community to actively support our students' growth and learning.
OUR VALUES: Innovation, Equity, Caring, Inclusion, Collaboration
Comments and Other Information Novato Unified School District prohibits, at any district school or school activity, discrimination, harassment, including sexual harassment, intimidation, and bullying, based on actual or perceived race, color, ancestry, nationality, national origin, immigration status, ethnic group identification, ethnicity, age, religion, marital status, pregnancy, parental status, physical or mental disability, sex, sexual orientation, gender, gender identity, gender expression, or genetic information, or association with a person or group with one or more of these actual or perceived characteristics. This shall apply when applicable, to interns, volunteers, and job applicants.
For questions, concerns or complaints, please contact: Title IX Coordinator, Francesca Whitcomb, 1015 Seventh Street, Novato, CA 94945, (415) 493-4207, uniformcomplaint@nusd.org; Section 504 Coordinator, Mike Saisi, 1015 Seventh Street, Novato, CA 94945, (415) 493-4269, msaisi@nusd.org; ADA/Title II Coordinator, Dr. Julie Synyard, 1015 Seventh Street, Novato, CA 94945, (415) 493-4227, jsynyard@nusd.org.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Coach - Girls' Basketball at Glinda Medina is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Assistant Coach - Girls' Basketball is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Glinda Medina, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Assistant Coach - Girls' Basketball helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Assistant Coach - Girls' Basketball works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Glinda Medina operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Glinda Medina with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Assistant Coach - Girls' Basketball reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Assistant Coach - Girls' Basketball role at Glinda Medina.

Job.JobTitle: Career Technical Education (CTE) Teacher - Sports Medicine (Health Science)
Job.JobDescription:
About the Employer CULVER CITY UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT At Culver City Unified School District, we take our responsibility seriously and are committed to excellence for all students in what we call The 4 A's: Academics, Athletics, Activities, and The Arts. Taking a Whole Child approach, our vision is that 100% of our students graduate from high school with unlimited opportunities in college and career, and are prepared to be successful in everything they endeavor to try.
Job Summary Under the direction of the site administrator, the CTE Sports Medicine Teacher will teach students about sports medicine, covering topics like anatomy, first aid, injury prevention, and rehabilitation for athletes. These programs provide hands-on experience, preparing students for careers in areas such as athletic training and physical therapy. Courses focus on the human body's response to physical activity, how to prevent common sports injuries, provide immediate care, and assist in the rehabilitation process. Candidates must have a strong desire to work with students to help them achieve their academic, personal, and professional goals.
Requirements / Qualifications QUALIFICATIONS Eligible to apply for the CTE Credential in Health Science Valid Athletic Training Certification from National Athletic Trainers' Association Knowledge of: Sports Medicine Sports Therapy Athletic Rehabilitation
CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT All employment offers are conditional, based upon the successful completion of the following: Fingerprint/background clearance and a tuberculosis clearance. A physical examination clearance is required for certain positions for the district. All candidates with a record of convictions must indicate such on the confidential/legal section of the application, which is attached to the job application. A record of conviction will not automatically disqualify an applicant from employment, but a failure to list all convictions may result in disqualification or dismissal.

Job.JobTitle: HEAD VARSITY FOOTBALL COACH - EHS - EUHSD
Job.JobDescription:
The HEAD VARSITY FOOTBALL COACH - EHS - EUHSD role at Kelly Landendorf Boden is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the HEAD VARSITY FOOTBALL COACH - EHS - EUHSD is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Kelly Landendorf Boden, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The HEAD VARSITY FOOTBALL COACH - EHS - EUHSD sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Kelly Landendorf Boden, the HEAD VARSITY FOOTBALL COACH - EHS - EUHSD is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the HEAD VARSITY FOOTBALL COACH - EHS - EUHSD at Kelly Landendorf Boden is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobDescription:
The Coach: Baseball - Varsity Assistant at Marcy Garcia is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Coach: Baseball - Varsity Assistant manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Marcy Garcia, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Coach: Baseball - Varsity Assistant demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Coach: Baseball - Varsity Assistant follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Coach: Baseball - Varsity Assistant at Marcy Garcia allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job.JobTitle: Coach: JV (Junior Varsity) Boys Volleyball Head coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Coach: JV (Junior Varsity) Boys Volleyball Head coach position at Marcy Garcia is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Coach: JV (Junior Varsity) Boys Volleyball Head coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Coach: JV (Junior Varsity) Boys Volleyball Head coach at Marcy Garcia sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Marcy Garcia, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Coach: JV (Junior Varsity) Boys Volleyball Head coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Coach: JV (Junior Varsity) Boys Volleyball Head coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Coach: JV (Junior Varsity) Boys Volleyball Head coach position at Marcy Garcia is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.
Job.Experience: Coaching experience desired

Job.JobTitle: 7th and 8th Track Coach- Tech Middle School
Job.JobDescription:
The 7th and 8th Track Coach- Tech Middle School role at Jasmine Sheeks is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the 7th and 8th Track Coach- Tech Middle School is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Jasmine Sheeks are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The 7th and 8th Track Coach- Tech Middle School listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the 7th and 8th Track Coach- Tech Middle School encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The 7th and 8th Track Coach- Tech Middle School follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Jasmine Sheeks, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the 7th and 8th Track Coach- Tech Middle School at Jasmine Sheeks, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription:
About the Employer Learning for a Lifetime - Committed to the Future We're proud to be a district creating innovative programs, opening schools, attracting students and preparing them for college and careers. Our vision is clear – all students are entitled to a successful education, our focus is learning and we are a team. This vision is shared by our community and we are thankful for the tremendous support we receive, which helps make our schools special places for children to learn. We have strong academic and enrichment programs, magnet programs and distinguished schools from transitional kindergarten through high school. Our district has received national recognition for our work in closing the achievement gap and increasing access to advanced curriculum for all students.
Job Summary CPR/First Aid course completion Applicable Coaching Courses Concussion Training Fundamentals of Coaching Course Sudden Cardiac Arrest
Requirements / Qualifications District Application (available at CRPUSD.org) Cover Letter Resume Letter(s) of Recommendation Copy of CPR & 1st Aid Cert. As part of the application process, applicants are required to submit a complete record of prior education-related employment. Employment contingent on receipt of clearance eligibility Please visit our website at www.CRPUSD.org for additional information Submission of this application authorizes any hiring official from CRPUSD to contact references provided. Due to the volume of applications we receive, we aren't able to give status updates, but if you are invited for an interview, you will be contacted directly by the hiring coordinator for that position.
Comments and Other Information Incomplete applications will not be considered. Please visit our website for futher information and district application at www.CRPUSD.org/job opportunities

About the Employer: The Governing Board is determined to provide a safe, positive environment where all district employees are assured of full and equal employment access and opportunities, protection from harassment and intimidation, and freedom from any fear of reprisal or retribution for asserting their employment rights in accordance with law. For purposes of this policy, employees include job applicants, interns, volunteers, and persons who contracted with the district to provide services, as applicable. No district employee shall be discriminated against or harassed by any coworker, supervisor, manager, or other person with whom the employee comes in contact in the course of employment, on the basis of the employee's actual or perceived race, color, ancestry, national origin, age, religious creed, marital status, pregnancy, physical or mental disability, medical condition, genetic information, military and veteran status, sex, sexual orientation, gender, gender identity, gender expression, or association with a person or group with one or more of these actual or perceived characteristics. The Division of Human Resources provides excellence in human resource leadership in support of the academic mission and our customers, the Manhattan Beach Community. We succeed by earning the satisfaction of our customers, the respect and trust of those who govern us, support us and do business with us; and the pride of our employees. Job Summary: Join the Mira Costa High School Color Guard/Winter Guard program. We are looking for an exceptional, experienced coach. Playing/Coaching experience in collegiate or High School Varsity level. The head coach organizes a program with various levels, develops a coaching staff, and develops players to compete at the highest level. Requirements / Qualifications: The MCHS Athletics Program: Provides opportunities for students to participate in a wide variety of sports throughout the school year. Assists participants in the development of required physical and sport-specific skills. Fosters the development of character, social skills, game ethics, and sportsmanship. Compliments lessons learned in the classroom and encourage cooperation, teamwork, discipline and hard work. Responsibilities include, but are not limited to: Communicate between the Athletics Director, other coaches, and key members of faculty and staff (primarily through email). When needed, assign duties to athletes to make sure their practice, game, pickup, and meeting areas are left as they found it. Encourage safe, respectful, and responsible behavior when hosting other teams or visiting other schools. Be mindful and considerate of the environment, buildings, and occupants both at home and away. Qualifications The ideal candidate will have a deep passion and knowledge of the sport, as well as a commitment to hands-on, student-centered coaching practices. We seek thoughtful, energetic, and passionate coaches who are committed to using multiple coaching modalities. We are also looking for genuine, kind colleagues and all-around "school people" who want to participate in and contribute to our vibrant community. Physical Requirements: Be able to stand and walk the court/field without difficulty for an extended period of time. Must be able to physically demonstrate the sport. Have or are willing to get: Teaching credential preferred. Valid CPR/First Aid Training Valid California Driver's License Concussion Training
Job.Experience: Playing/Coaching experience in collegiate or High School Varsity level
Job.SalaryRange: Pay dependent on experience, District Stipend paid at the end of the season.

The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Graham Middle School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Track and Field Coach listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Track and Field Coach encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Track and Field Coach follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Graham Middle School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Track and Field Coach at Graham Middle School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

About the Employer Join our team at North Monterey County Unified School District! NMCUSD serves over 4,400 students from preschool through adult education across Castroville, Prunedale, Moss Landing, Aromas, and parts of Salinas. Our student population is 91% Hispanic, 49% English Learners and 87% of our students are socioeconomically disadvantaged. Our mission, the reason we exist, is to ensure that all students graduate college, career, and life ready. The way in which we make our mission a reality is by upholding the following core values: To have high expectations for all students and to provide the necessary support so that every student receives what they need to thrive academically, socially and emotionally. To be culturally responsive, human centered and kind. To be inclusive, collaborate across differences and find common ground. To engage in continuous improvement and data based decision making. We are seeking passionate individuals who are committed to equity, inclusion, and making a real difference in students' lives. If this is you, apply today!
Requirements / Qualifications • Letter of Introduction (Letter must detail Softball coaching experience)
Comments and Other Information Successful candidates must submit verification of all required certifications for coaching in the State of California. Classified candidates may be considered if there is no interest from a certificated candidate Location: NMC High School

Join our team at North Monterey County Unified School District! NMCUSD serves over 4,400 students from preschool through adult education across Castroville, Prunedale, Moss Landing, Aromas, and parts of Salinas. Our student population is 91% Hispanic, 49% English Learners and 87% of our students are socioeconomically disadvantaged. Our mission, the reason we exist, is to ensure that all students graduate college, career, and life ready. The way in which we make our mission a reality is by upholding the following core values: To have high expectations for all students and to provide the necessary support so that every student receives what they need to thrive academically, socially and emotionally. To be culturally responsive, human centered and kind. To be inclusive, collaborate across differences and find common ground. To engage in continuous improvement and data based decision making. We are seeking passionate individuals who are committed to equity, inclusion, and making a real difference in students' lives. If this is you, apply today!
Job Summary
Under the direct supervision of the Principal, administrative designee, and/or the Athletic Director, is responsible for providing support, assisting with supervision, coordinating, organizing, staffing, and scheduling all interscholastic athletic events and related activities for the school in conjunction with the athletic program lead. Under the direction of the school site principal, administrative designee and/or the Athletic Director and in cooperation with staff, he/she plans, coordinates, and implements, the athletic program at the school in conformance with the California Interscholastic Federation, Education Code and District Policies. The Assistant Athletic Director is responsible to provide additional support for a quality athletic program that offers equal access for all students regardless of gender, race, religion, etc. The Assistant Athletic Director will be evaluated annually by the designated administrative supervisor on his or her performance of duties. The following statements are intended to describe the general nature and level of work being performed. They are not intended to be construed as an exhaustive list of all responsibilities, duties, and skills required of personnel so classified.
Requirements / Qualifications
* Letter of Introduction (Letter must detail track and field coaching experience)
Job.CompanyDescription: North Monterey County Unified coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The Cheer Coach LAHS position at Michelle Noeth is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Cheer Coach LAHS is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Michelle Noeth, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Cheer Coach LAHS encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Cheer Coach LAHS also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Cheer Coach LAHS role at Michelle Noeth is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.
Job.CompanyDescription: Mountain View-Los Altos Union H.Sch. coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The Rally Advisor LAHS at Michelle Noeth is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Rally Advisor LAHS manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Michelle Noeth, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Rally Advisor LAHS demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Rally Advisor LAHS follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Rally Advisor LAHS at Michelle Noeth allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job Summary: BHS is seeking Softball Coaches for the 2025-26 Season (Spring).
Requirements / Qualifications: Application, Resume, Professional Reference related to sport. Fingerprint and TB Clearance are required. All coaches paid and volunteer will need to apply for an Activity Supervisor Clearance Certificate (ASCC) if they do not already possess a valid document (Teaching credential or Substitute Permit) issued by the California Commission on Teacher Credentialing. About the Employer Welcome to Eureka City Schools: A Place to Learn, Lead, and Grow Thank you for your interest in becoming part of Eureka City Schools (ECS)—a district where every learner, every day is engaged, empowered, and future-ready. We are at an exciting crossroads, moving boldly toward a future where competency-based education replaces one-size-fits-all learning. Here, progress is measured by mastery and meaningful growth, not seat time. We’re building environments where every learner—students and staff alike—can flourish with personalized support, innovation, and purpose. Who We Are: Our Mission and Core Values At ECS, we are driven by a shared mission: Every Learner, Every Day: Engaged, Empowered, and Future-Ready. Our work is grounded in the following core values: Accountability – We act with integrity and follow through on our commitments. Empathy – We listen with compassion and foster understanding. Communication – We prioritize open, respectful, and honest dialogue. Innovation – We seek creative solutions to improve learning and engagement. Resilience – We approach challenges with grit and a growth mindset?. Guiding Principles for Learning We believe that: Learning is learner-centered and personalized. Belonging fosters growth—students learn best when they feel safe and seen. Equity means access—all learners deserve support tailored to their needs. Growth comes through effort, not perfection. Relevance drives engagement—learning should be joyful, authentic, and connected to life?. This commitment doesn’t stop with students. We extend these beliefs to every employee, creating a workplace where innovation, development, and excellence are supported every step of the way. Equity and Inclusion at the Core Eureka City Schools is proud to be an Equal Opportunity Employer. We believe that a diverse staff helps all learners thrive. Discrimination in any form—based on race, religion, ethnicity, gender, age, disability, or any protected category—is not tolerated. Our policies are guided by Title IX, Section 504, and other civil rights protections. Job Summary Previous wrestling coaching experience preferred. The coach must obtain the following prior to beginning of season: Coaching Certificate, Sudden Cardiac Arrest, Concussion, and Heat Illness Prevention Certificates (courses available online), Current CPR and First Aid Certification, Mandated Reporter training, DOJ and FBI fingerprint Clearance, Current TB Clearance. Applicants interested in this position should submit the following materials to Edjoin (edjoin.org): 1. Letter of Application 2. Résumé 3. District Application Form (Classified or Certificated) 4. Letters of Recommendation $2907 Stipend upon completion of training and assignment. ECS employees who work .5 FTE or more and provide a stipend service will receive an additional 5% of the stipend amount. The DNHS Head Volleyball Coach 26/27 position at Mary Martinez is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The DNHS Head Volleyball Coach 26/27 is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Mary Martinez, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The DNHS Head Volleyball Coach 26/27 encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The DNHS Head Volleyball Coach 26/27 also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the DNHS Head Volleyball Coach 26/27 role at Mary Martinez is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

About the Employer We're excited that you're considering joining the Parlier Unified School District family! Located in the heart of the San Joaquin Valley near the Sierra Nevada mountains, our district spans 20 square miles of Fresno County and serves a community of over 16,500 residents. Our district includes four elementary schools, one junior high, one comprehensive high school, a continuation school, and an adult school, with a total enrollment of just under 3,500 students. We are deeply student-centered and believe that with the right support, everyone can thrive. By focusing on Accomplished Students, a Supportive Environment, and an Empowered Community, we aim to create a culture where learning, teaching, and leadership flourish—every day, from everyone.

About the Employer Piedmont Unified School District (PUSD) is dedicated to providing all students with a comprehensive educational program that includes a broad-based curriculum, exemplary staff, and an environment that fosters a caring, equitable, and inclusive school environment for students. We value diverse thinkers who possess various experiences and viewpoints. We believe that a diverse workforce benefits all students, and our goal is to find the best staff who can uphold our values of excellence and equity for every student. Our goal is to ensure that all students graduate from high school ready for college and career, and are equipped with skills to thrive in an increasingly diverse 21st century society. PUSD serves approximately 2,400 students and consists of three elementary schools, one middle school, one traditional high school, and one alternative high school.
We prioritize assembling a staff that reflects our student diversity. We strongly encourage members of underrepresented groups and people of diverse backgrounds to apply.

Job.JobDescription:
The Varsity Co-Ed Golf Coach position at Adam Cano provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Varsity Co-Ed Golf Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Adam Cano, the Varsity Co-Ed Golf Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Varsity Co-Ed Golf Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Varsity Co-Ed Golf Coach at Adam Cano is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.
Job.Experience: Desirable

Job.JobDescription:
The Head Coach - Baseball at Susan McCoy is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Head Coach - Baseball plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Susan McCoy reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Head Coach - Baseball expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Head Coach - Baseball supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Head Coach - Baseball may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Susan McCoy. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

The Football - JV Head Coach (NOV #26-36) position at CUSD Business is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Football - JV Head Coach (NOV #26-36) works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Football - JV Head Coach (NOV #26-36) at CUSD Business sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At CUSD Business, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Football - JV Head Coach (NOV #26-36) encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Football - JV Head Coach (NOV #26-36) is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Football - JV Head Coach (NOV #26-36) position at CUSD Business is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

About the Employer The Riverdale Joint Unified School District is located approximately 25 miles southwest of Fresno in the heart of prime agricultural land. Farming and farm related enterprises are the principal businesses for the area.
Riverdale Joint Unified School District is a K-12 school district with four campuses, Fipps Primary (K-3), Riverdale Elementary (4-8), Riverdale High School (9-12) and Horizon High Continuation School (9-12). Riverdale Joint Unified School District provides services to more than 1600 students. Riverdale Joint Unified School District is fortunate to have a student body which is ethnically and culturally diverse.

The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Boys Tennis Head Coach at John Calonico sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At John Calonico, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Boys Tennis Head Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Boys Tennis Head Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Boys Tennis Head Coach position at John Calonico is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

The Girls Tennis Head Coach role at John Calonico emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Girls Tennis Head Coach coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At John Calonico, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Girls Tennis Head Coach reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent John Calonico at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Girls Tennis Head Coach may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Girls Tennis Head Coach monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Girls Tennis Head Coach must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at John Calonico.

Job.JobTitle: Middle School Cheer Coach- Fall Season
Job.JobDescription:
The Middle School Cheer Coach- Fall Season role at Jodi Pearson is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Middle School Cheer Coach- Fall Season is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Jodi Pearson are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Middle School Cheer Coach- Fall Season listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Middle School Cheer Coach- Fall Season encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Middle School Cheer Coach- Fall Season follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Jodi Pearson, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Middle School Cheer Coach- Fall Season at Jodi Pearson, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

The Wrestling Coach position at Jolene Towne is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Wrestling Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Wrestling Coach at Jolene Towne sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Jolene Towne, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Wrestling Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Wrestling Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Wrestling Coach position at Jolene Towne is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.JobDescription:
The 2026-2027 Fall Coaching Positions at Trena Smith is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the 2026-2027 Fall Coaching Positions are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Trena Smith use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The 2026-2027 Fall Coaching Positions recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the 2026-2027 Fall Coaching Positions collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The 2026-2027 Fall Coaching Positions maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Trena Smith. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.
