About the Employer: Imagine a school district that wins the San Diego County Academic Decathlon eight years in a row, that guarantees a college education to entire grade levels of children and where students excel in the arts as well as the classroom. At the Sweetwater Union High School District, our students and staff members have accomplished those feats and many more.
Founded in 1920, the Sweetwater District has grown to approximately 34,000 students in grades 7 through 12 and more than 10,000 adult learners. The district’s 32 campuses are located in the cities of Chula Vista, Imperial Beach, National City and San Diego, including the communities of Bonita, Eastlake, Otay Mesa, San Ysidro and South San Diego.
California’s richness in cultural, linguistic and economic diversity is reflected in Sweetwater’s student population, which includes Hispanic, Filipino, African-American, Asian and other ethnicities. Approximately half of Sweetwater’s students speak a language other than English at home.

Job.JobDescription:
Job Summary:
The Club Sport Coaches are responsible for the training and development of the Club Sport program at the University of San Francisco (USF). The goal of the program is to increase participation on campus and competitive performance through regional and national Club Sport competitions. The Club Sport Coach will serve as a leader of the team on and off the playing field. They will be responsible for upholding the mission and values of USF and the Recreational Sports Department (RSD). This position will report directly to the Assistant Director of Intramural and Club Sports.
Job Responsibilities:
Job Activities to include: • To coach the participants throughout the academic year and help with events and competitions. • To assist participants in distributing team information, posters, and leaflets. • To ensure that the participants are operating within the rules of the sport and USF while at home and away as a club. • To assist with collation of information and entries as necessary ensuring that all records are kept on database and information is disseminated as directed. • To attend organized club events and meetings as necessary. • To assist in ensuring that all waivers, memberships and insurance forms are kept up to date and maintained with the RSD. • To adhere to all of the procedures and quality standards for delivery, management and administration of USF Sport Clubs. • To undertake all such other duties as the management of the RSD shall direct. • The post holder will be able to refer matters to the Recreation Manager on a daily basis as necessary, for advice, guidance and consultation. • Attendance at all practice sessions, matches and tournaments is required. Working Knowledge: There is a need to adhere to: • General health and safety as it pertains to the sport. • Data protection. • Player protection. • Injury reports and prevention. Records and Reports: • Monthly reports and record keeping are expected. The post holder will compile and record information, results, entries etc. All records and files need to be kept and communicated with the Recreation Manager. Minimum Requirements: Education and Experience High School Diploma or GED is required. 2 years of coaching experience at the high school, club, or collegiate level Knowledge, Skills and Abilities • Experience in coaching students in an educational environment. • Experience organizing, supervising and running training sessions/practices, matches, and events. • Experience recruiting students/athletes. • Ability to work with students, staff and faculty in a professional manner.

Job.JobTitle: Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching-Athletics Pool
Job.JobDescription:
The Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching-Athletics Pool at San Joaquin Delta College is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching-Athletics Pool is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At San Joaquin Delta College, the Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching-Athletics Pool helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching-Athletics Pool may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents San Joaquin Delta College well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching-Athletics Pool follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

The Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching (Cheer Team) Pool role at San Joaquin Delta College is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching (Cheer Team) Pool is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Coaches at San Joaquin Delta College are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching (Cheer Team) Pool listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching (Cheer Team) Pool encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching (Cheer Team) Pool follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At San Joaquin Delta College, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching (Cheer Team) Pool at San Joaquin Delta College, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

About the Employer We are a unified school district serving more than 16,150 students in grades K -12. We have thirteen elementary schools, four middle schools, two comprehensive high schools, three specialized high schools, two alternative high schools and one K-8 school. We also offer a home schooling program, adult education courses and other unique programs to fit the needs of all students. Our school district employs approximately 1,100 certificated and nearly 900 classified employees.
Antioch Unified School District is centrally located in the East Bay and provides ready access to scenic mountains, waterfronts, wine country, historical sites and the Pacific Ocean. Antioch is known as the "Gateway to the Delta" and is one of California's oldest cities, with a diverse community of approximately 100,000.
The Antioch Unified School District is a Merit System District. As such, final selection of our classified staff members will be made from candidates who have been placed on an eligibility list. Eligibility is determined via an evaluation and competitive screening/scoring of a candidate’s training and experience as demonstrated on the application and responses provided in the supplemental questions.

Job.JobDescription:
The Varsity Track Head Coach role at Calipatria Unified emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Varsity Track Head Coach coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Calipatria Unified, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Varsity Track Head Coach reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Calipatria Unified at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Varsity Track Head Coach may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Varsity Track Head Coach monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Varsity Track Head Coach must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Calipatria Unified.
Job.Location: Calipatria Unified - Calipatria, Imperial County, CA

Job.JobDescription:
The Athletic Coach Only at Clear Creek ISD is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Athletic Coach Only plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Clear Creek ISD reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Athletic Coach Only expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Athletic Coach Only supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Athletic Coach Only may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Clear Creek ISD. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

The Athletic Trainer Pool 2025 position at Brownsville Independent School District is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Athletic Trainer Pool 2025 works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Athletic Trainer Pool 2025 at Brownsville Independent School District sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Brownsville Independent School District, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Athletic Trainer Pool 2025 encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Athletic Trainer Pool 2025 is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Athletic Trainer Pool 2025 position at Brownsville Independent School District is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.JobTitle: Campus Athletic Coordinator / Head Football Coach
Secondary Social Studies Teacher & Football/Baseball Coach (25-26)
Job.JobDescription:
Primary Purpose: Provide students with appropriate learning activities and experiences designed to fulfill their potential for intellectual, emotional, physical, and social growth. Enable students to develop competencies and skills to function successfully in society.
Qualifications: Bachelor's degree from an accredited university Valid Texas teaching certificate with required endorsements for subject and level assigned. ESL Certification required for all ELA teachers. Knowledge of subjects assigned. General knowledge of design and delivery issues related to alignment for best results in student achievement. Ability to deliver instruction and manage student behavior. Strong organizational, communication, and interpersonal skills Student teaching or approved internship
Major Responsibilities and Duties: 1. Develop and implement lesson plans that fulfill the requirements of district's curriculum program and show written evidence of preparation as required. 2. Prepare lessons that reflect accommodations for differences in student learning styles. 3. Present subject matter according to guidelines established by Texas Education Agency, board policies, and administrative regulations. 4. Plan and use appropriate instructional and learning strategies, activities, materials, and equipment that reflect accommodation for the individual needs of students assigned. 5. Conduct assessment of student learning preferences and use results to plan instructional activities. 6. Work cooperatively with special education teachers to modify curricula as needed for special education students according to guidelines established in Individual Education Plans (IEP). 7. Cooperate with other members of staff for planning and implementing instructional goals, objectives, and methods according to district requirements. 8. Plan and supervise purposeful assignments of teacher aide(s) and volunteer(s). 9. Use technology to strengthen the teaching/learning process. 10. Assist students in analyzing and improving study methods and habits. 11. Consistently evaluate student achievement through formal and informal assessments and use results to plan instructional activities.
Working Conditions: May require standing for long periods of time Repetitive hand motions and prolonged use of a computer. The position requires frequent bending, stooping, twisting, pulling, overhead reaching, sitting, and keyboarding. Position requires the ability to lift 25 pounds to waist high. Must have the ability to move small stacks of textbooks, media equipment, desks, and other classroom equipment. Ability to communicate effectively (verbal and written); ability to instruct; maintain emotional control under stress.
This document describes the general purpose and responsibilities assigned to this job and is not an exhaustive list of all responsibilities and duties that may be assigned, alternative methods of performing your duties, or skills that may be required.

Job.JobTitle: Middle School Athletic Trainer/ PE Teacher for Polk MS, Perry MS
Job.JobDescription:
Primary Purpose:
Athletic Training Services: The management and provision of care of injuries to a physically active person as defined in the state practice act with the direction of a licensed physician. The term includes the rendering of emergency care, development of injury prevention programs and providing appropriate preventative and devices for the physically active person. The term also includes the assessment, management, treatment, rehabilitation and recondition of the physically active person whose conditions are within the professional preparation and education of a certified athletic trainer. The term also includes the use of modalities such as mechanical stimulation, heat, cold, light, air, water, electricity, sound, massage and the use of therapeutic exercises, reconditioning exercise and fitness programs.
Qualifications:
Education/Certification: • Bachelor's degree, Masters preferred • Licensed by the State of Texas as an Athletic Trainer, ATC preferred • Valid State of Texas teaching certificate.
Major Responsibilities and Duties: Injury Prevention: • Develop and implement comprehensive injury prevention programs tailored to individual athletes and teams. • Educate athletes, coaches, and staff on injury prevention techniques, proper nutrition, and physical conditioning. • Conduct pre-participation physical exams to identify potential risk factors for injury. Injury Evaluation and Treatment: • Provide on-site emergency care and treatment for acute sports injuries. • Evaluate athletic injuries, determining the nature and severity of the injury. • Develop and implement appropriate treatment and rehabilitation plans, ensuring a safe return to activity. Rehabilitation: • Design and monitor personalized rehabilitation programs for injured athletes. • Utilize therapeutic modalities, exercises, and manual therapy techniques to aid in recovery. • Collaborate with healthcare providers, including physicians and physical therapists, to ensure comprehensive care. Documentation and Reporting: • Maintain accurate and up-to-date medical records for all athletes. • Document injury evaluations, treatments, and rehabilitation progress in compliance with legal and ethical standards. • Provide regular reports on injury trends and outcomes to the appropriate personnel. Collaboration and Communication: • Work closely with coaches, team physicians, and other medical professionals to ensure the well-being of athletes. • Communicate effectively with athletes and their families regarding injury status, treatment plans, and expected outcomes. Compliance and Professional Development: • Stay current with industry best practices and continuing education requirements to maintain certification and licensure. • Ensure compliance with all relevant regulations, standards, and guidelines, including those set by professional organizations and governing bodies.
In addition to being the Head Athletic Trainer:
• Maintain appropriate general treatment orders to be reviewed annually and approved by the team physician. • Provide athletic training services for all home athletic contests and away varsity football games. • If a conflict arises between an away varsity football game and a home contest, the varsity football event will supersede. • Act as liaison between family physicians and specialists, the school district, athletes and their parents. • Develop and maintain a budget for the athletic training program. • Schedule and be present for pre-participation physicals. • Provide the coaches and athletic director with a list of athletes medically eligible to compete under district and state rules and regulations. • Assist the athletic director as requested.
In addition to being the Middle School Trainer:
• Teach sections of a content area such as PE or CTE. • Coverage would be at two campuses; alternating days. • Maintain appropriate general treatment orders to be reviewed annually and approved by the team physician. • Provide athletic training services for all home athletic contests for middle school at campus and possibly at other campuses as well as Standridge Stadium. • Act as liaison between family physicians and specialists, the school district, athletes and their parents. • Maintain accurate records of injuries, treatments and provide insurance claim forms for sports injuries treated by a physician. • Schedule and be present for pre-participation sports physicals. • Provide the coaches and athletic director with a list of athletes medically eligible to compete under district and state rules and regulations. • Assist head athletic trainer as requested at the high school level when needed.
Supervisory Responsibilities: None
Working Conditions: Mental Demands/Physical Demands/Environmental Factors: Long hours, weeknight coverage and some weekend coverage. Possible lifting, bending, walking, kneeling, stretching, and stooping. Requires eye-hand coordination and manual dexterity. Requires normal hearing and eyesight to allow for patient interaction and transfer of patient information from the patient to pen chart. Need to have the ability to handle high amounts of stress. Also, exposed to climate conditions such as but not limited to heat, rain, sleet, snow, and cold temperatures. Ability to communicate effectively (verbal and written); interpret policy, procedures, and data; maintain emotional control under stress. The foregoing statements describe the general purpose and responsibilities assigned to this job and are not an exhaustive list of all responsibilities and duties that may be assigned or skills that may be required.
Reviewed by: Renee Putter Dec 5, 2025 Approved by: Kyalla Bowens Dec 18, 2025

Job.JobTitle: MS Athletic Coordinator/ Head Football Coach
Job.JobDescription:
Primary Purpose: To help each student participate in high school athletics, achieve a high degree of skill and appreciation for the values of discipline and sportsmanship and an increased level of self-esteem.
Qualifications: Education/Certification:
Minimum of a bachelor’s degree. Demonstrated skill and competence in planning, organizing, and directing student athletic activities. Valid Texas teaching certificate or such other credentials as may be required by the State Board for Educator Certification for this position.
Special Knowledge/Skills:
Possess strong analytical, organizational, and leadership skills Demonstrate effective communication, public relation, and interpersonal skills.
Experience:
A minimum of 4 years’ experience as a high school Varsity Offensive/Defensive play caller. High School Head Football Coaching experience preferred.
Major Responsibilities and Duties:
Support all phases of the athletic program and encourage athletes to participate in every sport in which they have talent and interest. Be responsible for ensuring that all rules, regulations, guidelines, and policies of TEA, UIL, and Carrollton-Farmers Branch ISD are followed at his/her campus. Assist the athletic department, Human Resources department, and principal in recruiting and interviewing coaching personnel and follow required district personnel procedures to fill vacancies on the coaching staff at the high school. Evaluate head coaches in each sport, athletic trainers, and all assistant football coaches and approve the evaluations of all other assistant coaches by their head coach and ensure that the evaluation process is conducted according to C-FB ISD policy. Work with the principal and Athletic Director in providing information for the development of the master schedule to ensure, the most advantageous use of coaching personnel, athletic periods, conference periods, and optimum utilization of facilities. Prepare duty rosters, schedule, and secure working personnel for sub-varsity football games, basketball games, baseball games, track and wrestling meets, and other athletic events as needed. Keep the principal and Athletic Director informed of needs and problems within the athletic program. Collect, check, and forward to the athletic department the proposed schedule of interschool games and scrimmages for all sports on campus and be available to assist head coaches with scheduling, if needed. Coordinate transportation request with the athletic and transportation departments for all sports on campus. Work with head coaches to ensure that bid request and inventories for all sports are completed and turned in on time and receive and disperse equipment for all sports on campus. Assist the principal and Athletic Director in improving and maintaining the athletic fields, gymnasiums, courts, and tracks on campus. Attend all UIL District meetings with the principal and Athletic Director as a representative of the school and athletic department when requested by the administration. Promote the athletic program with the media, civic groups, booster groups, parent and school organizations and assist head coaches in promoting their teams and their sports. Work with the middle school, feeder school and coaches to develop lines of communication, coordination and continuity with the total high school sports program, with special emphasis on the transition from middle school and the retention of student athletes in the program. Work with the administration and head coaches to find ways to reduce academic athletic ineligibility. See that all coaches on campus are provided with office space, keys, office supplies, facilities, materials and equipment as needed. Ensure that all coaches have a notarized UIL “Professional Acknowledgement” form on file with the Athletic Department Office. Maintain necessary eligibility forms, physical examinations forms, grade reports, transfer forms, and insurance information relevant to student athletes. Operate the summer conditioning program. Assist the Director of Athletics during summer months. Set an appropriate example for athletes and co-workers in the areas of personal behavior, speech, dress, and good sportsmanship. Perform all other duties as deemed necessary by the Superintendent or designee
Working Conditions: Mental Demands/Physical Demands/Environmental Factors: Ability to communicate effectively (verbal and written); interpret policy, procedures, and data; coordinate district functions; maintain emotional control under stress. District and statewide travel; occasional prolonged and irregular hours.
The foregoing statements describe the general purpose and responsibilities assigned to this job and are not an exhaustive list of all responsibilities and duties that may be assigned or skills that may be required.
Job.Experience: A minimum of 4 years’ experience as a high school Varsity Offensive/Defensive play caller.

Job.JobTitle: Drill Team/Dance Teacher - Tomball West High School- 2026-2027 School Year
Job.JobDescription:
The Drill Team/Dance Teacher - Tomball West High School- 2026-2027 School Year position at TOMBALL WEST HIGH SCHOOL is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Drill Team/Dance Teacher - Tomball West High School- 2026-2027 School Year is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At TOMBALL WEST HIGH SCHOOL, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Drill Team/Dance Teacher - Tomball West High School- 2026-2027 School Year encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Drill Team/Dance Teacher - Tomball West High School- 2026-2027 School Year also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Drill Team/Dance Teacher - Tomball West High School- 2026-2027 School Year role at TOMBALL WEST HIGH SCHOOL is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.
Job.Location: TOMBALL WEST HIGH SCHOOL - Tomball, Texas

Job.JobDescription:
The High School - Teacher / Coach Pool 2026 - 2027 at Birdville Independent is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the High School - Teacher / Coach Pool 2026 - 2027 is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Birdville Independent, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The High School - Teacher / Coach Pool 2026 - 2027 helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The High School - Teacher / Coach Pool 2026 - 2027 works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Birdville Independent operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Birdville Independent with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the High School - Teacher / Coach Pool 2026 - 2027 reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the High School - Teacher / Coach Pool 2026 - 2027 role at Birdville Independent.
Job.Location: Birdville ISD - To Be Determined - Haltom City, Texas

The coach must also manage the budget and care for the equipment and facilities. Job.JobTitle: HS Coach, Head Volleyball (Open Teaching Assignment)
Job.JobDescription:
The HS Coach, Head Volleyball (Open Teaching Assignment) at Travis Bryan High School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the HS Coach, Head Volleyball (Open Teaching Assignment) is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Travis Bryan High School, the HS Coach, Head Volleyball (Open Teaching Assignment) helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The HS Coach, Head Volleyball (Open Teaching Assignment) may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Travis Bryan High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The HS Coach, Head Volleyball (Open Teaching Assignment) follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Primary Purpose: Plan, coordinate, and supervise all components of athletic training program for student athletes. Also work under the direction of team physician to carry out activities in the following areas: prevention, evaluation, emergency treatment, physical reconditioning, and rehabilitation of injuries
Qualifications: Education/Certification: Bachelor’s degree Valid license from Texas Advisory Board of Athletic Trainers
Special Knowledge/Skills: Ability to provide injury prevention and rehabilitation services Ability to provide emergency care Knowledge of therapeutic modalities and ability to apply appropriate treatment to treat student athletic injuries Ability to instruct and supervise student athletes and assistants Excellent organizational, communication, and interpersonal skills Experience: Two years experience as an athletic trainer preferred Major Responsibilities and Duties:Working Conditions: 1. Plan and implement a comprehensive athletic injury and illness prevention program for student athletics. 2. Attend practice sessions and athletic contests as assigned by athletic director. 3. Evaluate athletic injuries and determine treatment and rehabilitation for student athletes. 4. Establish and maintain effective communication with students, parents, medical and paramedical personnel, coaches, and other staff. 5. Provide physical conditioning training to student athletes. 6. Maintain training room and therapeutic equipment. 7. Fit injured athletes with specialized equipment and oversee its use. 8. Monitor, provide training, and set daily activities for student trainers. 9. Maintain file of Athletic Participation Permits which parents use to give approval for participation in athletics, for physical examinations, for emergency medical treatment, and for specific information on student health as required. 10. Maintain records on athletic injuries, referrals to physicians, and treatments given. 11. Perform other duties as assigned. Mental Demands/Physical Demands/Environmental Factors: Maintain emotional control under stress. Work with frequent interruptions. Continual walking and standing; moderate to heavy lifting and carrying; stooping, bending, kneeling, and reaching. Work outside (exposure to sun, heat, cold, and inclement weather) and inside. Exposure to biological hazards, bacteria, and communicable diseases. Frequent districtwide and statewide travel; frequent prolonged and irregular hours. Use of Dell and Macintosh computers and related equipment, copier, fax machine, and cellular phone.
Note: This is not necessarily an exhaustive or all-inclusive list of responsibilities, skills, duties, requirements, efforts, functions or working conditions associated with the job. Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Football Coach/Special Education Teacher role at Temple High School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Assistant Football Coach/Special Education Teacher is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Temple High School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Assistant Football Coach/Special Education Teacher listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Assistant Football Coach/Special Education Teacher encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Assistant Football Coach/Special Education Teacher follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Temple High School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Assistant Football Coach/Special Education Teacher at Temple High School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.Location: Temple High School 415 North 31st Street Temple, TX 76504

Job.JobDescription:
Primary Purpose:
Provide athletic training services to district athletes under the direction of the team physician (and Head Athletic Trainer) in order to provide for the care, prevention, treatment, and rehabilitation of athletic injuries and illnesses.
Qualifications:
Education/Certification:
Bachelor’s degree in Athletic Training or related field Texas Board of Athletic Trainers License (LAT) or Certification by the Board of Certification (BOC) Current CPR/AED/First Aid certification
Experience:
Experience working with secondary school athletes Experience managing multiple sites or schedules Knowledge of UIL regulations and Texas school athletic policies
Major Responsibilities and Duties:
· Assist in the planning and implementation of a comprehensive athletic injury and illness prevention program for student athletes.
· Attend practice sessions and athletic contests as assigned by AD, Assistant AD and Head Athletic Trainer.
· Be available for HOME events (7th through Varsity) as assigned.
· Establish and maintain effective communication with students, parents, medical and paramedical personnel, coaches, and other staff.
· Prepare athletes for games and practices by conducting evaluations and using tape, wraps, splints, braces, & other protective devices as needed.
· Respond to emergencies and make quick, independent judgments about how to deal with injuries.
· Identify acute injuries and provide first-aid triage, including assessing injuries and deciding whether an athlete should seek further medical attention and should discontinue participation in the athletic event.
· Assist the Head Athletic Trainer in establishing specific procedures to be carried out by a coach or student athletic trainer in the event of a medical emergency.
· Compile, maintain, and file all physical and computerized reports, records, and other documents including doctor, accident, and treatment records as required.
· Maintain an inventory of training supplies and equipment.
· Assist with the organization and monitoring of UIL required physical examinations for all athletics 7-12.
· Assist the Head Athletic trainers with all Staff Development pertaining to athlete safety in accordance w/ State mandates and UIL Policies.
· Communicate utilizing the prescribed chain of command.
· Perform other duties assigned by the Athletic Director and Head Athletic Trainer.
Leadership Qualities:
· Models a Commitment to Excellence by setting direction for campus departments, utilizing innovative approaches to challenges, and achieving results by prioritizing needs, adjusting plans, and optimizing resources.
· Has the ability to Connect with All by building trust across campus departments and within the community, creating collaborative processes that value varying perspectives, and providing clear and transparent communication.
· Seeks opportunities to Invest in Growth by developing self, empowering others, and embracing reflective practices that encourages growth toward goal attainment among staff.
Supervisory Responsibilities:
Direct the work of student assistants.
Mental Demands/Physical Demands/Environmental Factors:
Tools/Equipment Used: Exercise equipment and devices including stationary bike, pulleys, weights, whirlpool, paraffin bath, ultrasound equipment, and cold packs; automated external defibrillator (AED)
Posture: Prolonged standing; frequent kneeling/squatting, bending/stooping, pushing/pulling, and twisting
Motion: Continual walking; moderate reaching
Lifting: Frequently moderate lifting or carrying (15-44 pounds)
Environment: Work outside (exposure to sun, heat, cold, and inclement weather) and inside; exposure to noise; exposure to biological hazards, bacteria, and communicable diseases; frequent districtwide and statewide travel
Mental Demands: Maintain emotional control under stress; frequent prolonged and irregular hours

Job.JobTitle: Girls Coach/Core Subject or Special Education Teacher
Job.JobDescription:
This posting is for all teaching positions for the 2025-2026 school year.
SUMMARY
Provide students with appropriate learning activities and experiences in the core academic subject area assigned to help them fulfill their potential for intellectual, emotional, physical, and social growth. Enable students to develop competencies and skills to function successfully in society. Provide instruction and coach students to develop skills and ability to excel in assigned sport(s). Contribute to education program as a whole and to growth of students involved in athletics.
Qualifications:
Education/Certification: Bachelor's degree from accredited university Valid Texas teaching certificate with required endorsements or related training and work experience for certification waivers under the District of Innovation Plan (DOI) Demonstrated competency in the core academic subject area assigned Current automated external defibrillator (AED) and cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) certificate] Clear and valid Texas commercial driver’s license with Passenger (P) and School Bus (S) endorsements
Special Knowledge/Skills: Assist the Head Volleyball coach with directing and supervising the volleyball program at the high school level. Knowledge of core academic subject assigned, coaching techniques, and procedures. Knowledge of curriculum and instruction Knowledge of University Interscholastic League (UIL) rules Ability to instruct and supervise student athletes Ability to instruct students and manage their behavior Strong organizational, communication, and interpersonal skills
Experience: Student teaching, approved internship, or related work experience 2 years of high school/college volleyball coaching
Major Responsibilities and Duties:
Instructional Strategies 1. Develop and implement lesson plans that fulfill the requirements of district’s curriculum program and show written evidence of preparation as required. Prepare lessons that reflect accommodations for differences in individual student differences. 2. Plan and use appropriate instructional and learning strategies, activities, materials, equipment, and technology that reflect understanding of the learning styles and needs of students assigned and present subject matter according to guidelines established by Texas Education Agency, board policies, and administrative regulations. 3. Conduct assessment of student learning styles and use results to plan instructional activities. 4. Work cooperatively with special education teachers to modify curricula as needed for special education students according to guidelines established in Individual Education Plans (IEP). 5. Work with other members of staff to determine instructional goals, objectives, and methods according to district requirements. 6. Plan and assign work to instructional aide(s) and volunteer(s) and oversee completion. 7. Use a variety of instructional techniques and media to meet the needs and improve the abilities of student athletes in the sport assigned. 8. Assist with the management and supervision of athletic activities, contests, and practice sessions to promote individual growth in athletic skills, teamwork, and good sportsmanship. 9. Use technology to strengthen the teaching/learning process.
Classroom Management and Organization 10. Create classroom environment conducive to learning and appropriate for the physical, social, and emotional development of students. 11. Manage student behavior in accordance with Student Code of Conduct and student handbook. 12. Take all necessary and reasonable precautions to protect students, equipment, materials, and facilities. 13. Assist in selecting books, equipment, and other instructional materials. 14. Assist with the compilation, maintenance, and filing of all reports, records, and other documents required. 15. Assist with the process of cleaning, repairing, and storing all campus athletic equipment. 16. Compile, maintain, and file all reports, records, and other documents required.
Communication 17. Establish and maintain a professional relationship and open communication with parents, students, colleagues, and community members.
Professional Growth and Development 18. Participate in staff development activities to improve job-related skills. 19. Comply with state, district, and school regulations and policies for classroom teachers. 20. Attend and participate in faculty meetings and serve on staff committees as required.
Leadership Qualities Models a Commitment to Excellence by embracing a shared vision for the campus, utilizing innovative approaches to that align to the school vision and influence the school community to contribute to the vision's realization.
Other 21. Follow district safety protocols and emergency procedures. 22. Maintain an appropriate level of confidentiality regarding students, staff, and school district information. 23. Ensure compliance with all local policies and state and federal statutes including the Educator Code of Ethics. 24. Comply with all district and campus routines and regulations. 25. Perform other duties as assigned.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Soccer Coach at High School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Assistant Soccer Coach are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at High School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Assistant Soccer Coach recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Assistant Soccer Coach collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Assistant Soccer Coach maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at High School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.SalaryRange: Commensurate with TCISD hiring salary guide. Stipend based on sport(s) coached.

Job.JobTitle: 9-12th Grade COACH/Classroom Teacher (Pool for 2026-2027 School Year)
Job.JobDescription:
The 9-12th Grade COACH/Classroom Teacher at Lovejoy High School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the 9-12th Grade COACH/Classroom Teacher is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Lovejoy High School, the 9-12th Grade COACH/Classroom Teacher helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The 9-12th Grade COACH/Classroom Teacher may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Lovejoy High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The 9-12th Grade COACH/Classroom Teacher follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.
Job.SalaryRange: Teacher Pay Scale: based on creditable years of service, 187 Workday Calendar

Job.JobDescription:
The High School Head Volleyball Coach/Teacher role at Lovejoy High School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the High School Head Volleyball Coach/Teacher is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Lovejoy High School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The High School Head Volleyball Coach/Teacher sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Lovejoy High School, the High School Head Volleyball Coach/Teacher is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the High School Head Volleyball Coach/Teacher at Lovejoy High School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobTitle: 7-8th Grade COACH/Classroom Teacher (Pool for 2026-2027 School Year)
Job.JobDescription:
The 7-8th Grade COACH/Classroom Teacher role at Willow Springs Middle School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the 7-8th Grade COACH/Classroom Teacher is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Willow Springs Middle School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The 7-8th Grade COACH/Classroom Teacher listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the 7-8th Grade COACH/Classroom Teacher encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The 7-8th Grade COACH/Classroom Teacher follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Willow Springs Middle School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the 7-8th Grade COACH/Classroom Teacher at Willow Springs Middle School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription: Job Title: Athletic Trainer Exemption Status/Test: Exempt/Professional Reports to: Athletic Director Date Revised: 1/7/2026 Dept./School: Athletics Primary Purpose: Implement a comprehensive athletic training program for student athletes including the prevention, care, and rehabilitation of athletic injuries as well as the coordination of athletic physical examinations and screening. Qualifications: Education/Certification: Bachelor’s degree Valid license issued by the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation Certified Athletic Trainer (ATC) CPR, First Aid, and AED certified Special Knowledge/Skills: Knowledge of therapeutic modalities and injury prevention Ability to provide emergency care and rehabilitation for student athletic injuries Ability to instruct and supervise student athletes and assistants Strong organizational, communication, and interpersonal skills Experience: 0 years of experience as an athletic trainer Major Responsibilities and Duties: 1. Plan and implement a comprehensive program to prevent athletic injuries and illnesses among student athletes. 2. Provide physical conditioning training to student athletes. 3. Attend practice sessions and athletic contests and prepare athletes using protective techniques and devices as needed. 4. Provide emergency or continued care and refer athletes to physicians for definitive diagnosis and treatment. 5. Detect and resolve risks to athletes and determine whether they can continue participating in athletic events. 6. Develop and establish specific procedures to be carried out in the event of a medical emergency. 7. Provide health care information and counsel, and instruct student athletes on subject matter related to athletic training. 8. Establish and maintain effective communication with students, parents, medical and paramedical personnel, coaches, and other staff. Rehabilitation/Reconditioning 1. Plan and implement a comprehensive rehabilitation and reconditioning program for injuries and illnesses sustained by student athletes. 2. Determine therapeutic goals and objectives for individual athletes, apply therapeutic modalities, and instruct athletes on proper use of exercise equipment. 3. Fit injured athletes with specialized equipment and oversee its use. 4. Evaluate and record the rehabilitation progress of athletes. Develop criteria for progression and return to practice and competition. 5. Follow and enforce professional, ethical, and legal parameters regarding the use of drugs and therapeutic agents for the treatment and rehabilitation of injured athletes. Administration 1. Coordinate scheduling of athletic physical examinations and screening. 2. Select, train, and supervise student assistants. 3. Compile, maintain, and file all reports, records, and other documents, including medical, accident, and treatment records as required. 4. Maintain an inventory of training supplies and equipment to ensure a consistent supply. Requisition additional supplies as needed. 5. Follow district safety protocols and emergency procedures. Supervisory Responsibilities: Direct the work of student assistants. Mental Demands/Physical Demands/Environmental Factors: Tools/Equipment Used: Exercise equipment and devices, including a stationary bike, pulleys, weights, whirlpool, paraffin bath, ultrasound equipment, and cold packs; an automated external defibrillator (AED) Posture: Prolonged standing; frequent kneeling/squatting, bending/stooping, pushing/pulling, and twisting Motion: Continual walking; moderate reaching Lifting: Frequently moderate lifting or carrying (15-44 pounds) Environment: Work outside (exposure to sun, heat, cold, and inclement weather) and inside; exposure to noise; exposure to biological hazards, bacteria, and communicable diseases; frequent district-wide and statewide travel Mental Demands: Maintain emotional control under stress; frequent, prolonged and irregular hours This document describes the general purpose and responsibilities assigned to this job and is not an exhaustive list of all responsibilities and duties that may be assigned or skills that may be required.

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 - Boy's Lacrosse - Junior Varsity Assistant Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 - Boy's Lacrosse - Junior Varsity Assistant Coach at San Dieguito High School Academy is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the 2025-2026 - Boy's Lacrosse - Junior Varsity Assistant Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at San Dieguito High School Academy reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The 2025-2026 - Boy's Lacrosse - Junior Varsity Assistant Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the 2025-2026 - Boy's Lacrosse - Junior Varsity Assistant Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the 2025-2026 - Boy's Lacrosse - Junior Varsity Assistant Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at San Dieguito High School Academy. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.
