Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 - Boy's Lacrosse @ 50% - Varsity Assistant Coach position at San Dieguito High School Academy is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the 2025-2026 - Boy's Lacrosse @ 50% - Varsity Assistant Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The 2025-2026 - Boy's Lacrosse @ 50% - Varsity Assistant Coach at San Dieguito High School Academy sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At San Dieguito High School Academy, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The 2025-2026 - Boy's Lacrosse @ 50% - Varsity Assistant Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The 2025-2026 - Boy's Lacrosse @ 50% - Varsity Assistant Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the 2025-2026 - Boy's Lacrosse @ 50% - Varsity Assistant Coach position at San Dieguito High School Academy is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.
Job.CompanyDescription: San Dieguito Union H.S. Dist. coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 - Baseball @ 50% - Freshmen Assistant Coach position at La Costa Canyon High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the 2025-2026 - Baseball @ 50% - Freshmen Assistant Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At La Costa Canyon High School, the 2025-2026 - Baseball @ 50% - Freshmen Assistant Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The 2025-2026 - Baseball @ 50% - Freshmen Assistant Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the 2025-2026 - Baseball @ 50% - Freshmen Assistant Coach at La Costa Canyon High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.
Job.CompanyDescription: San Dieguito Union H.S. Dist. coaching jobs

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 - Boy's Track & Field - Varsity Assistant Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 - Boy's Track & Field - Varsity Assistant Coach at Canyon Crest Academy is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the 2025-2026 - Boy's Track & Field - Varsity Assistant Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Canyon Crest Academy reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The 2025-2026 - Boy's Track & Field - Varsity Assistant Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the 2025-2026 - Boy's Track & Field - Varsity Assistant Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the 2025-2026 - Boy's Track & Field - Varsity Assistant Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Canyon Crest Academy. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobDescription: QUALIFICATIONS: 1. Has the ability to organize and supervise a total sports program. 2. Has previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport. (Major sports) 3. The head coach must have substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and, at the same time, must continue to examine new theories and procedures pertinent to the field. 4. The head coach must serve as an appropriate role model for student athletes through his/her instructions and actions. REPORTS TO: The athletic director, who provides overall objectives and final evaluation in conjunction with the high school principals SUPERVISES: In several instances, the head coach must advise, coordinate and support a staff of high school assistant coaches and middle school coaches in conjunction with the athletic director and respective principal. JOB GOAL: To instruct athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the coach must instruct and demonstrate behaviors that lead to socially acceptable character development, self discipline, self confidence, and pride of accomplishment in the student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc. GENERAL: 1. The success of athletic programs has a strong influence on the community's image of the entire system. The public exposure is a considerable responsibility and community/parent pressure for winning performance is taxing, but must not override the objectives of good sportsmanship and good mental health. 2. The position includes other unusual aspect such as extended time, risk injury factor and due process predicaments. 3. It is the express intent of this job description to give sufficient guidance to function. In cases not specifically covered, it shall be assumed that a coach shall exercise common sense and good judgment. DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: 1. Has a thorough knowledge of all the athletic policies approved by the Plainwell Community Schools’ Board of Education and is responsible for their implementation by the entire staff of the sports program. 2. Has knowledge of existing system, state and league regulations; implements same consistently and interprets them for staff. 3. Understands the proper administrative line of command and refers all requests or grievances through proper channels. Is aware of all public/staff/departmental meetings that require attendance. STAFF RESPONSIBILITIES:

Job.JobTitle: Coach - Head Track and Field - Marysville High School
Job.JobDescription:
Job Summary Marysville High School is seeking a qualified, experienced Head Varsity Track & Field Coach. The successful candidates will have demonstrated competencies in the following areas: • Will stress the fundamentals of the game (skill & strategy), conduct practices, and supervise games and transportation. • Knowledge and competency related to care and prevention of athletic injuries, basic first aid and emergency procedures. • Knowledge and competency in coaching theory and techniques in the sport being coached. • Knowledge and competency in the rules and regulations of the sport, state, section, league, and district policies. • Knowledge of psychology of the adolescent or child. • Knowledge of the Code of Ethical Conduct.
Requirements / Qualifications MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS: • CPR/ First Aid Certification • A General Coaching Education Course • Concussion Training • Sudden Cardiac Arrest (SCA) Training • Heat Acclimatization Course
Comments and Other Information ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: • Manage and supervise athletic activities, contests, and practice sessions, to promote individual growth in athletic skills, teamwork, discipline, respect, and good sportsmanship. • Use a variety of instructional techniques and media to meet the needs and improve the abilities of student athletes. • Coordinate the development, promotion and recruitment for the Track & Field Program. • Develop a regular practice schedule and organize practice time to provide both individual and team development. • Encourage sportsmanlike conduct in all phases of athletic participation at all times. • Represent the Marysville Joint Unified School District, Marysville High School and the Athletic Programs in a professional manner.

Job.JobTitle: VOLLEYBALL - HEAD VARSITY GIRLS COACH - Homestead High School
Job.JobDescription:
The VOLLEYBALL - HEAD VARSITY GIRLS COACH - Homestead High School at Homestead High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the VOLLEYBALL - HEAD VARSITY GIRLS COACH - Homestead High School is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Homestead High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The VOLLEYBALL - HEAD VARSITY GIRLS COACH - Homestead High School helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The VOLLEYBALL - HEAD VARSITY GIRLS COACH - Homestead High School works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Homestead High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Homestead High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the VOLLEYBALL - HEAD VARSITY GIRLS COACH - Homestead High School reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the VOLLEYBALL - HEAD VARSITY GIRLS COACH - Homestead High School role at Homestead High School.

Job.JobTitle: FOOTBALL - ASSISTANT VARSITY COACH - Lynbrook High School
Job.JobDescription:
The FOOTBALL - ASSISTANT VARSITY COACH - Lynbrook High School at Lynbrook High School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the FOOTBALL - ASSISTANT VARSITY COACH - Lynbrook High School is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Lynbrook High School, the FOOTBALL - ASSISTANT VARSITY COACH - Lynbrook High School helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The FOOTBALL - ASSISTANT VARSITY COACH - Lynbrook High School may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Lynbrook High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The FOOTBALL - ASSISTANT VARSITY COACH - Lynbrook High School follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobTitle: VOLLEYBALL - HEAD JV GIRLS COACH - Fremont High School
Job.JobDescription:
The VOLLEYBALL - HEAD JV GIRLS COACH - Fremont High School role at Fremont High School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the VOLLEYBALL - HEAD JV GIRLS COACH - Fremont High School is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Fremont High School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The VOLLEYBALL - HEAD JV GIRLS COACH - Fremont High School sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Fremont High School, the VOLLEYBALL - HEAD JV GIRLS COACH - Fremont High School is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the VOLLEYBALL - HEAD JV GIRLS COACH - Fremont High School at Fremont High School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobTitle: DANCE TEAM ADVISOR - Monta Vista High School
Job.JobDescription:
The DANCE TEAM ADVISOR - Monta Vista High School position at Monta Vista High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the DANCE TEAM ADVISOR - Monta Vista High School prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Monta Vista High School, the DANCE TEAM ADVISOR - Monta Vista High School works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The DANCE TEAM ADVISOR - Monta Vista High School encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the DANCE TEAM ADVISOR - Monta Vista High School at Monta Vista High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobTitle: Coach - Assistant Coach Boys Swim - San Luis Obispo High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Coach - Assistant Coach Boys Swim - San Luis Obispo High School position at San Luis Obispo High School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Coach - Assistant Coach Boys Swim - San Luis Obispo High School works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Coach - Assistant Coach Boys Swim - San Luis Obispo High School at San Luis Obispo High School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At San Luis Obispo High School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Coach - Assistant Coach Boys Swim - San Luis Obispo High School encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Coach - Assistant Coach Boys Swim - San Luis Obispo High School is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Coach - Assistant Coach Boys Swim - San Luis Obispo High School position at San Luis Obispo High School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.JobDescription: JOB TITLE: Track and Field Coach (6 positions available) -Hurdles -High Jump -Long and Triple Jump -Throwing -Long Distance JOB DESCRIPTION: MVWSD middle schools are seeking Activities Coach for after school sports programs. WORK DAYS: Season 5 - April 7, 2026 - May 14, 2026 Depending on level of championship and extended play RATE OF PAY: $2,000 stipend. Additional $50 stipend per playoff game - depending on length of season/level of championship. (Stipends will be split for shared coaching positions). REQUIRED CERTIFICATION: Applicants must be certified under Title V, C.C.R. Section 5593 and 5594, prior to the beginning of the season of sport. The following certifications must be completed before assuming individual coaching duties: * Current TB examination * Mandated Child Abuse Reporter (www.mandatedreporterca.com) * First Aid and CPR (American Heart Association or American Red Cross) * NFHS - Fundamentals of Coaching * NFHS - Concussion in Sports * NFHS - Sudden Cardiac Arrest * NFHS - Heat Illness Prevention Note: NFHS trainings and certifications available online at www.nfhslearn.com
Job.SalaryRange: $2,000 stipend. Additional $50 stipend per playoff game

Job.JobDescription:
The Track and Field Coach at Crittenden Middle School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Track and Field Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Crittenden Middle School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Track and Field Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Track and Field Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Track and Field Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Crittenden Middle School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job Summary The La Cañada High School Athletics Department has an opening for the Boys Varsity Head Water Polo Coach. The team practices the full year and has its competitive season in the fall, approximately August through October. The chosen candidate will be asked to start in the position as soon as background clearances are received, including fingerprinting results and tuberculosis screening.
Requirements / Qualifications Application Procedure: 1. Current LCUSD employees may submit a letter of interest to Human Resources. Outside parties may submit an electronic application through the posting on EdJoin (www.edjoin.org/lcusd). The EdJoin application should include a coaching resume, references with contact information, and at least three (3) recent letters of reference/recommendation. An introduction letter and/or coaching portfolio are welcome but not required. Letters may be addressed to:
Dr. Debra Cradduck, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources La Cañada Unified School District 4490 Cornishon Avenue La Cañada, CA 91011
2. After applications have been screened, candidates will be contacted for a personal interview with an interview panel. Interviews will be conducted in person at La Cañada High School.
Items below are required for an application to be considered:
Letter(s) of Recommendation (at least 3 current letters) Resume (with references, including contact information)
Comments and Other Information Qualifications: 1. Experience: Two years or more of successful experience coaching high school, collegiate or elite/club water polo. 2. Licenses: Current first aid and CPR certifications.
Work Calendar: The competitive season ranges approximately August through October. The varsity head coach may be asked to work with the team year-round, including summers, for practice and strength training. The chosen candidate will assume coaching responsibilities as soon as clearance is confirmed from a background check, tuberculosis skin test reading and completion of the onboarding process.
Compensation: The stipend for this position is $4,010.00 annually, paid as a lump sum at the conclusion of the competitive season. Additional compensation is paid at a daily rate for the length of time the team participates in CIF finals. The daily rate for CIF compensation is calculated by dividing the regular stipend by the number of days in the regular season
Benefits: This position does not meet the eligibility requirements to participate in the District’s health and welfare benefits.
Job.Experience: Two years or more

Job.JobTitle: Boys JV Volleyball Head Coach - Saratoga High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Boys JV Volleyball Head Coach - Saratoga High School at Vanessa Garces is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Boys JV Volleyball Head Coach - Saratoga High School manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Vanessa Garces, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Boys JV Volleyball Head Coach - Saratoga High School demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Boys JV Volleyball Head Coach - Saratoga High School follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Boys JV Volleyball Head Coach - Saratoga High School at Vanessa Garces allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job.JobDescription:
The JV Softball Coach at Aaron Brooks is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the JV Softball Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Aaron Brooks, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The JV Softball Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The JV Softball Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Aaron Brooks operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Aaron Brooks with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the JV Softball Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the JV Softball Coach role at Aaron Brooks.

Job.JobTitle: Varsity Girls Flag Football Coach - Escalon High School
Job.JobDescription:
About the Employer: Escalon Unified School District spans approximately 161 square miles and is located in southern San Joaquin County along the northern back of the Stanislaus River. The district was formed in 1967 from the unification of seven elementary districts and one secondary district. EUSD values our supportive community as well as productive collaboration amongst our professional staff which promotes effective teaching and improved student learning. With 3000 students and over 300 staff members, our eight school sites engage our student learners in a variety of ways including Dual Language Immersion, K-12 Home School, Career Technical Education programs such as Agriculture, Computer Programming and First Responders, Advanced Placement, K-12 music and much more. Escalon Unified School District strategically recruits, hires, develops, and retains the highest quality staff to ensure that all EUSD students learn at high levels. We encourage you to view our website and follow us on our Facebook page.
Requirements / Qualifications: Varsity Girls Flag Football Coach at Escalon High School for the 2026-2027 School Year. Fall Sport.

Job.JobDescription: All Athletic Coach hires and work schedules for the school year are contingent upon student enrollment, sports sign ups, and sports schedules developed for the season. Attenda all required meetings and trainings as specified by OAL. QUALIFICATIONS: All Candidates must meet all of the requirements listed below. Preference will be given to current certificated employees of Oakland Unified School District who possess a valid CA teaching credential. The following certifications are required: Injury prevention/treatment: Valid, current CPR card AND Valid, current First Aid card OR proof of completing a college-level course in the care/prevention of athletic injuries OR a valid EMT I or II card OR A valid Sports Injury Certificate. Sudden Cardiac Arrest. Concussion. Heat illness prevention. Fundamentals of coaching training (high school) OR Coaching Essentials training (middle school). COVID Safety. College courses or prior active involvement with youth in school/community sports programs will fulfill this requirement. Knowledge, skill and ability sufficient to maintain high standards of safety in all aspects of coaching at practices as well as contests. Demonstrated high ethical standards related to sportsmanship, fair play and relationships with students. Knowledge of school policies and California Interscholastic Federation (C.I.F.) policies related to athletics. Overall Applicant Assessment: Applicant must be able to meet the standards for the district's athletic program as carried out at each site, including the ability to instill teamwork, commitment and discipline as to players, developing positive relations and support from parents and the community and offering academic encouragement and support to students. Job.JobTitle: Flag Football Head Coach @ Mt. Diablo High School #3924
Job.JobDescription: STANDARDS FOR ATHLETIC TEAM COACHES The following standards are minimum qualifications for applicants to athletic team coach positions in the Mt. Diablo Unified School District. Knowledge, training, and demonstrated competency in the following areas are required to qualify for any athletic coach position in the District. 1. Knowledge and Competencies: Knowledge and competency related to care and prevention of athletic injuries, basic first aid and emergency procedures which may be evidenced by one or more of the following: Completion of a college-level course in the care and prevention of athletic injuries and possession of a valid cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) card. A valid sports injury certificated or first aid card, and a valid cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) card. 2. Coaching Techniques: The coach shall be knowledgeable in coaching theory and techniques in the sport or game being coached as evidenced by one or more of the following: Completion of a college course in coaching theory and techniques of the specific sport. Completion of in-service programs arranged by a school district or county office of education in the specific sport. Prior services as a head or assistant athletic coach in the specific sport. Prior participation in organized competitive athletics at high school level or above in the sport being coached. 3. Rules and Regulations in the Athletic Activity Being Coached including: Training and knowledge of the rules and regulations in the athletic activity being coached and demonstrated ability to communicate those rules and regulations in an e?ective, respectful manner which instills teamwork, commitment and discipline. The coach shall have knowledge of the rules and regulations of the North Coast Section pertaining to the sport or game being coached, the league rules, and regulations of the California Interscholastic Federation. Additional Competencies for Non-certificated Personnel In addition to the competencies listed above, it shall be determined that a non-certificated person employed as a temporary athletic coach: Has not been convicted of any offense referred to in Education Code 44010, 44011 or 44424, or any offense involving moral turpitude or evidencing unfitness to associate with children. Is free from tuberculosis and any other contagious disease that would prohibit certi?cated teachers from teaching, as verified by a written statement, renewable every four years, from a licensed physician or other person approved by the district 5. Code of Ethical Conduct: Applicants for athletic team coach positions shall be expected to demonstrate knowledge, training and competency to insure compliance with the following Code of Ethical Conduct. In addition, all athletic team coaches providing supervisory or instructional services in interscholastic athletic programs shall abide by the Code of Ethical Conduct. Show respect for players, o?cials, other coaches and parents Respect the integrity and judgment of game o?cials. Establish and model fair play, sportsmanship and proper conduct. Establish player safety and welfare as the highest priority. Provide an environment that instills teamwork, commitment and discipline. Provide leadership which promotes a positive experience for the student athlete. Provide proper supervision of students at all times. Use discretion when providing constructive criticism and when reprimanding players. Maintain consistency in requiring all players to adhere to the established rules and standards of the game. Properly instruct players in the safe use of equipment. Avoid exerting undue influence on a student's decision to enroll in an athletic program at any public or private postsecondary educational institution. Avoid exerting undue influence on students to take lighter academic course(s) in order to be eligible to participate in athletics. Avoid suggesting, providing or encouraging any athlete to use non-prescriptive drugs, anabolic steroids or any substance to increase physical development or performance that is not approved by the Food and Drug Administration, U.S. Surgeon General or the American Medical Association. Avoid recruitment of athletes from other schools. Work e?ectively with booster groups. Work e?ectively with school administration. Position Type: Part-Time Job Categories: Athletics & Activities > Coaching Job Requirements: Citizenship, residency or work visa required

Job.JobTitle: HEAD COACH - GIRLS TENNIS@DEL CAMPO HIGH SCHOOL #7000
Job.JobDescription:
The HEAD COACH - GIRLS TENNIS@DEL CAMPO HIGH SCHOOL #7000 position at Geoffrey Gill is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The HEAD COACH - GIRLS TENNIS@DEL CAMPO HIGH SCHOOL #7000 is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Geoffrey Gill, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The HEAD COACH - GIRLS TENNIS@DEL CAMPO HIGH SCHOOL #7000 encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The HEAD COACH - GIRLS TENNIS@DEL CAMPO HIGH SCHOOL #7000 also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the HEAD COACH - GIRLS TENNIS@DEL CAMPO HIGH SCHOOL #7000 role at Geoffrey Gill is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.
Job.CompanyDescription: San Juan Unified School District coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The recreation coach 3 - 136581 position at University of California - San Diego provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the recreation coach 3 - 136581 prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At University of California - San Diego, the recreation coach 3 - 136581 works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The recreation coach 3 - 136581 encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the recreation coach 3 - 136581 at University of California - San Diego is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Athletic Trainer position at Hope International University is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Assistant Athletic Trainer is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Hope International University, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Assistant Athletic Trainer encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Assistant Athletic Trainer also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Assistant Athletic Trainer role at Hope International University is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Coach, Men's and Women's Swimming
Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Coach for Men and Women's Swimming and Diving responsible for providing assistance and support for the conduct of a comprehensive, high quality NCAA Division I men's and women's swimming programs, within the guidelines of all rules and policies established by the department, the institution, the MPSF Conference, and the NCAA, in accordance with the academic standards, and the stated mission of Saint Mary's College and the Athletic Department.
This positon will require daily and/or weekly duties and tasks as assigned by the head coach which require exercising discretion and independent judgment consisting of 75% instructional and 25% recruitment/administrative activities.
1. Organize and evaluate practices, training plans and intercollegiate competitions. Teach necessary skills from the basic fundamentals to the techniques and strategies of team play. 2. Promote and foster a positive team environment, appropriate behavior, and sportsmanship by team members. Responsible for the conduct of team members both on and off the field. Promote the physical and mental well-being of all program participants. 3. Responsible for the academic performance of team members including graduation from the College. Support, monitor, and evaluate the academic performance of the student-athletes participating in the sport program. Work closely with Student-Athlete Services to assist student-athletes as needed with their academic success. 4. Recruit and select qualified prospects who have the ability to compete in the classroom and athletically. Actively seek out and encourage a diverse group of prospects and assist them through the application process. Work collaboratively with Student-Athlete Services and the Admissions Office staff to qualify and process prospects in a timely and efficient manner and in accordance with all College, Conference and NCAA policies. 5. Assist in developing and implementing a public relations/ fundraising plan to promote and advance the swimming program and athletics within the College and the surrounding community. Represent the College at various on and off-campus events. Be an active participant in departmental fundraising activities. 6. Comply with all College, Conference, and NCAA rules and regulations. Know, recognize, and comply with the laws, policies, rules, and regulations governing the College and its employees, and the rules of the National Collegiate Athletic Association (including, but not limited to, NCAA Bylaw, Article 11 and its requirement to report all athletically-related income and benefits from sources outside of the College to the President) and of the MPSF Conference as now constituted or as may be amended in the future. Supervise and ensure that any assistants and any other employees and/or volunteers for whom you are administratively responsible comply with the aforesaid policies, rules and regulations. Immediately advise the Vice President for Intercollegiate Athletics if you have reasonable cause to believe violations, whether by employees or students, have occurred or will occur.
Requirements Education: REQUIRED: Bachelor's degree PREFERRED: Master's Degree Experience: 1 to 2 years of progressive experience in swim coaching required,
1 to 2 years of progressive experience in the conduct of a collegiate level men's and women's swimming program with proven success in recruiting high quality student athletes and/or equivalent related experiences preferred Working Knowledge of Team Manager and Meet Manager
Skills/Abilities: Strong interpersonal skills with the ability to deal with all levels of coaches, administrators and staff. Strong organizational skills with the ability to handle multiple tasks and priorities. Proficiency with word software and database management. Team-oriented individual with the ability to take initiative. Ability to represent the Department and College in a professional manner to on and off campus constituencies, including alumni, friends, corporate partners and donors. Ability to maintain confidentiality and use discretion. Licenses & Certifications CPR/AED and Lifeguard Trainer Certification (or acquire with in 6 months Other Requirements: Must be able to travel and work weekends and nights. Salary Description $70,304.00
Job.Experience: 1 to 2 years
Job.CompanyDescription: Saint Mary's College of California coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The Track Coach, 6th/7th Grade role at Livermore Valley Joint Unified S.D. is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Track Coach, 6th/7th Grade is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Livermore Valley Joint Unified S.D., teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Track Coach, 6th/7th Grade sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Livermore Valley Joint Unified S.D., the Track Coach, 6th/7th Grade is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Track Coach, 6th/7th Grade at Livermore Valley Joint Unified S.D. is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.
Job.CompanyDescription: Livermore Valley Joint Unified S.D. coaching jobs

SB 848 COMPLIANCE – EFFECTIVE JANUARY 1, 2026
Effective January 1, 2026, and in accordance with California Education Code Section 44051(a)(1), any applicant for a non-teaching position must disclose a complete list of every school district, county office of education, charter school, state special school and diagnostic center operated by the department of education, and private school that the applicant has previously been an employee of, including full-time, part-time, or substitute roles. Requirements / Qualifications Demonstrates knowledge of the fundamental skills and techniques, as well as the advanced techniques needed for the Sport. Demonstrates successful ability to teach, enforce, advocate and model appropriate behavior, character traits and educational values to student athletes. Demonstrates successful ability to follow the National Federation of High Schools Coaches Code of Conduct and the California Interscholastic Federation Coaches Code of Conduct Requires Sport experience and prefer experience working with youth. Open till filled. A one-time stipend is paid out at the end of each coaching season: Fall Coaching in December Winter Coaching in March Spring Coaching in June

Job.JobDescription:
Position Information: The Athletic Trainer position oversees the healthcare management of assigned sports, and serves as the primary point of contact between sports medicine, coaching staff, and student-athletes. The Athletic Trainer collaborates closely with team physicians, strength and conditioning staff, dietitians, and mental health professionals to develop individualized performance and injury prevention programs that optimize student-athlete health and performance. This position is responsible for the prevention, evaluation, treatment, and rehabilitation of athletic injuries and illnesses while ensuring compliance with NCAA, conference, and institutional health and safety standards. The Athletic Trainer also plays a critical role in enhancing the student-athlete experience by fostering a culture of health, safety, and performance excellence while contributing to the advancement of sports medicine services at the institution.
Requirements: Educational Requirements Degree: Bachelor's degree in related area. Required Degree: Master's degree in related field. Preferred
Experience Requirements Experience: 4 - 7 years of related experience. Required
Certification Requirements Certification: Professional certification. Required Certification: First Aid, CPR and AED Required
Special Conditions: Travel Outside of Normal Business Hours Required Travel Required Work schedule will include evening and weekend hours. Required Valid Drivers License Required
Minimum Requirements: Computer skills in programs relevant to job duties. Thorough skills associated with athletic injury prevention and the administration of therapeutic modalities, devices, and rehabilitation techniques, as well as of first-aid, athletic equipment, and injury assessment and treatment. Ability to maintain discretion and confidentiality in handling sensitive matters involving athletic injuries and treatments. Thorough knowledge of electronic medical records systems. For positions associated with Sports Medicine, must maintain current knowledge of applicable rules and standards of the affiliated athletic conference, the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) or National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics (NAIA), as well as other associations and agencies to which the campus adheres, and, at all times, avoid any and all violations of these rules and standards. Strong ability to work in a highly collaborative manner with others, including athletes, team physicians, faculty, staff and others in the athletic department.

Job.JobDescription:
The Boys Volleyball Assistant Coach at Jessie Ceja is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Boys Volleyball Assistant Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Jessie Ceja, the Boys Volleyball Assistant Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Boys Volleyball Assistant Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Jessie Ceja well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Boys Volleyball Assistant Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.
Job.Experience: Previous Coaching Experience

Job.JobDescription: About the Employer MISSION: The mission of the Rialto Unified School District, the bridge that connects students to their aspirations for the future, is to ensure each student achieves personal and career fulfillment within a global society, through a vital system distinguished by: High expectations for student achievement Safe and engaging learning environments Effective family and com munity involvement Learning opportunities beyond the traditional school setting Appreciation of universal diversity BELIEFS: We believe that... Everyone has unique talent There is boundless power in all of us All people have equal inherent worth Diversity is strength Each person deserves respect High expectation inspires high achievement Risk is essential to success Common and individual interest are reciprocal Integrity is critical to trust Honest conversation leads to understanding Music is the universal language A strong community benefits all of its members Everyone can contribute to the good of the community Requirements / Qualifications MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS • A minimum of three years coaching experience within the sport at the high school, college or club level. • Varsity Assistant coaches need one year of playing or coaching experience at the high school, college or club level. • A verifiable record of having been part of a winning tradition, including post season C.I.F. playoff competition as a coach is desirable. • A proven verifiable record of positive staff, student and administrative support and relationships. • A proven verifiable record of placing appropriate emphasis on good sportsmanship, academic excellence, positive attitudes and character. • A demonstrated ability to work with parents and athletic booster clubs. • A demonstrated ability to successfully promote athletes who qualify under NCAA Clearinghouse standards for post secondary scholarship opportunities. • A demonstrated ability to serve as a positive role model for student athletes and a commitment to holding all students and adults associated with the program to the same standards. • A long term commitment to develop and sustain a positive, winning tradition JOB REQUIREMENTS: Applicants must be certified under Title V, C.C.R. Section 5593 and 5594, prior to the beginning of the CIF season of sport. The training and certification is available to all coaches on-line at www.nfhslearn.com . The following certifications must be completed before assuming individual coaching duties: • Fingerprints (Will be done upon selection of candidate) • First Aid and CPR (CPR must be an in-person course AND Both First Aid and CPR must be from the American Heart Association or the American Red Cross) • CIF Fundamentals of Coaching Certification • CIF Concussion in Sports Certification • CIF Heat Illness Prevention Certification • CIF Sudden Cardiac Arrest Certification • Current T.B. examination • Mandated Child Abuse Reporter Certification (Will be done upon selection of candidate) APPLICATION PROCESS: Applications from qualified candidates are invited. A complete application file is required and consists of: • A completed EDJOIN application • An up-to-date resume • Two (2) recent letters of recommendation are REQUIRED. The letters must be signed and dated within the last 2 years. Acceptable Signatures are: electronic document (Docusign or similar platform) or handwritten scanned signatures. Typed signatures will not be accepted To submit an application you must log onto www.edjoin.org. Applicants are responsible for assuring that Human Resources receive the online application submission of their application before the deadline. Applicants must be sure they are submitting a complete application packet with all required documents.
Job.Experience: 3 years
