Job.JobTitle: Head Coach, Boys Wrestling - HIGHLAND HIGH
Job.JobDescription:
Head Coach – Boys Wrestling (Highland High School)
Highland High School is seeking a passionate and committed individual to serve as the Head Coach for Boys Wrestling. This position is essential to the continued growth and success of the boys wrestling program and plays a critical role in promoting athletic excellence, personal development, sportsmanship, and school pride.
Preferred Qualifications:
Previous high school wrestling coaching experience is preferred but not required Experience working with high school students in an athletic or mentorship capacity Demonstrated ability to develop athletes at various skill levels Strong organizational, communication, and leadership skills
Required Certifications/Trainings:
The following certifications must be completed and uploaded to coach.registermyathlete.com upon job offer and prior to completing a criminal background check:
Coaching Endorsement (PE/Coaching Degree or NFHS “Fundamentals of Coaching”) Current First Aid and CPR Certification NFHS “Concussion in Sport” NFHS “Sudden Cardiac Arrest” NFHS “Heat Illness Prevention” NFHS “Bullying, Hazing, and Inappropriate Behaviors” Child Sexual Abuse Prevention Training Utah Educator Professional Standards (Read and E-sign) Annual Salt Lake City School District Athletic Coach Training SLCSD Vector Trainings (to be completed after hire and before beginning any coaching responsibilities)
Upon appointment, SLCSD FERPA/Student Privacy trainings will also be required. For questions regarding certifications or trainings, please contact the school's Athletic Director.
Position Type: Part-Time
Contact Information Human Resources 406 E 100 S Salt Lake City, Utah 84111 Phone: 801.578.8340 Email: jobs@slcschools.org
Job.CompanyDescription: Salt Lake School Dist coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
Position Type: Coaching/Extracurricular/Athletic Coach
Date Posted: 10/29/2025
Location: Stansbury High School
Closing Date: Open until filled
Description: Assistant Baseball Coach (2 Positions Available)
Job Summary: Instructs students in the fundamental skills of the sport/activity. Creates an environment that's conducive to personal development for team members through observing and evaluating as well as emphasizing teamwork and providing guidance for each student athlete. Develops sport-specific drill and practice activities to enhance the team's performance including exercises, game plans and teaching specific training rules to each player. Motivates students to do their best in academic studies and sports performance. Maintains a positive image for the school and team.
Oversees sporting trips and events that are beneficial to the team and the school. Engages in pep rallies and school meetings. Maintains team equipment, participates in the hiring and instructing of assistant coaches, and assists in scheduling sports activities while following a budget that conforms to the districts regulations.
Qualifications:
Must have a high school diploma or equivalent Must be at least 21 years of age Familiar with the rules and regulations of the sport/activity Experience as an athlete and/or coach Work closely with program assistant coach(es) Ability to motivate, teach, and lead Be energetic, responsible, dependable, self motivated and punctual Have excellent public relation skills and work effectively with staff, parents and administration

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Coach - Girls Lacrosse - Canyon View High School
Job.JobDescription: Do you want meaningful work? This is your place. We want you to join our team! Come work for the Iron County School District in Cedar City, UT and help to make a difference in the lives of students and families in your community! Canyon View High School is seeking an Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach. This position will remain open until filled. Must be willing to learn and use all computer systems and software as needed. Please see the Full Job Description at the link HERE

Job.JobDescription:
We want you on our team! Work in a place where you can feel valued for what you do and make a difference in the lives of student athletes in our community!
Parowan High School is seeking a Head Drill Coach.
This position will remain open until filled.
Head Coach is responsible for coaching student athletes in game strategies and techniques to prepare them for athletic competition; motivates student athletes to develop an appreciation of the sport.
• Holds organizational meetings for team prospects and encourages potential athletes to participate in the sport. • Assesses player’s skills and assigns team positions. • Develops a regular practice schedule and organizes practice time to provide both individual and team development. • Works with the School Athletics Director in scheduling facilities for practices and competition. • Ensures and monitors training and certification compliance, mandated by Utah High School Athletic Association (UHSAA), for all assigned assistant coaches and volunteers. • Coaches and instructs players, individually or in groups, regarding the rules, regulations, equipment, and techniques of the sport. • Observes players, during competition and practice to determine the needs for individual or team improvement. • Determines game strategy based on the team’s capabilities. • Establishes and maintains standards of pupil behavior and provides proper supervision of athletes at all times. • Monitors the academic performance of team members to ensure that eligibility requirements are met. • Follows established procedures in the event of an athlete’s injury. • Conferences with parents/guardians, as necessary, regarding the athletic performance of their student. • Follows state, regional, and district regulations governing the athletic program. • Models sports-like behavior and maintains appropriate conduct towards players, officials, and spectators. • Acts as a team representative and promotes the sport by communicating with the news media, booster clubs, service clubs, and other organizations. • Responsible for scheduling travel requests and also turning in a “Spend Plan” annually. • Follows established procedures for the proper care, maintenance, and requisitioning of equipment, supplies, and uniforms. • Works with the School Athletic Director to develop a policy for awards and submits a list of award winners at the end of the season. • Participates in special activities to include banquets, award nights, and assemblies.

Job.JobDescription:
Title: HEAD COACH - ATHLETICS (JV)
Position Type: Supplement
Primary Function:
Position is responsible for assisting the head coach with organizing the program at the assigned school. Position assists with conducting practices, motivating students, and instructing student athletes in game strategies and techniques.
Minimum Qualifications:
Prior successful coaching experience at the secondary level preferred
Knowledge, Skills and Abilities:
Must possess excellent organizational skills and the ability to handle details accurately. Ability to work effectively and maintain composure under pressure. Must possess the ability to establish and maintain effective working relationships with school administrators, parents, and students.
Performance Responsibilities:
Assists the head coach with instructing players in the rules, regulations, equipment, and techniques of the designated sport. Organizes and directs individual and small group practice activities/exercises as directed by the head coach.

Job.JobDescription:
All coaching positions are posted as open until filled. Any applicants that apply within 5 days of initial posting are guaranteed consideration per the Coaches collective bargaining agreement.
Persons applying for paid coaching positions must meet district and WIAA requirements including a valid background check. Applicants for head coaching positions must be at least 21 years of age. Applicants for assistant coaching positions must be at least 19 years of age. They must also have a valid first aid and CPR card. The following procedures must be followed to apply for paid coaching positions:
1. Complete the KSD online application process including professional reference forms. 2. Annually complete the WIAA general rules clinic, the WIAA-approved rule clinic for the sport being coached, and the KSD Vector Training requirements prior to the beginning of the sports season. 3. Have successfully completed Concussion recognition and management with Return to Play Protocols training as required by Washington State Law that must be renewed every three (3) years. 4. Have successfully completed Sudden Cardiac Arrest Awareness and Training as required by Washington State Law that must be renewed every three (3) years. 5. Before the beginning of the third year of coaching, a member school coach (paid or volunteer) must complete a school district-approved Coaching Principles training, or complete the NFHS Coaches Fundamentals Course, or attend all sessions of the WIAA Coaches School, or other Coaches School as approved by the WIAA or the local school district. After initial completion, coaches will be required to repeat this training every three (3) years. 6. Building athletic directors will monitor the applicant pool for their open positions and contact applicants as necessary. 7. If hired, the paid coach must read and sign the KSD Coaches Manual.
Job.Benefits: Employee Benefits | Kent School District

The ASSISTANT COACH - GIRLS TENNIS position at Emerald Ridge High School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the ASSISTANT COACH - GIRLS TENNIS works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The ASSISTANT COACH - GIRLS TENNIS at Emerald Ridge High School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Emerald Ridge High School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The ASSISTANT COACH - GIRLS TENNIS encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The ASSISTANT COACH - GIRLS TENNIS is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the ASSISTANT COACH - GIRLS TENNIS position at Emerald Ridge High School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

The ASSISTANT COACH - BOYS SOCCER position at Rogers High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the ASSISTANT COACH - BOYS SOCCER prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Rogers High School, the ASSISTANT COACH - BOYS SOCCER works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The ASSISTANT COACH - BOYS SOCCER encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the ASSISTANT COACH - BOYS SOCCER at Rogers High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

BASIC QUALIFICATIONS: 1. Enthusiasm for athletics. 2. Available for all related activities. 3. Demonstrates knowledge of assigned sports fundamentals. 4. Organizational and motivational skills. 5. Ability to model behavior as outlined in Coaches Handbook. 6. Successful coaching experience and training over a period of years. 7. Willingness to support the total athletic program. 8. Current First Aid and C.P.R. card. 9. Those recommended for hire must attend a training class on Hepatitis B and HIV, receive vaccination for Hepatitis B if necessary, and take the district's class on sexual harassment training. 10. Those recommended for hire will be fingerprinted for a background check. 11. Pursuant to WIAA Regulations, Head coaches must be 21 years of age; Assistant coaches must be 19 years of age. 12. Class room teacher is preferred but, not required.

All individuals may be reached at this address: 516 176th Street East, Spanaway, WA 98387. Title IX inquiries may also be directed toward the U.S. Department of Education, Office for Civil Rights (OCR) https://www2.ed.gov/about/offices/list/ocr/index.html . Information about the nondiscrimination and sex-based discrimination policies and grievance procedures, and how to report a concern or complaint: bethelsd.org.

Job.JobDescription:
BASIC QUALIFICATIONS: 1. Enthusiasm for athletics. 2. Available for all related activities. 3. Demonstrates knowledge of assigned sports fundamentals. 4. Organizational and motivational skills. 5. Ability to model behavior as outlined in Coaches Handbook. 6. Successful coaching experience and training over a period of years. 7. Willingness to support the total athletic program. 8. Current First Aid and C.P.R. card. 9. Those recommended for hire must attend a training class on Hepatitis B and HIV, receive vaccination for Hepatitis B if necessary, and take the district's class on sexual harassment training. 10. Those recommended for hire will be fingerprinted for a background check. 11. Pursuant to WIAA Regulations, Head coaches must be 21 years of age; Assistant coaches must be 19 years of age. 12. Class room teacher is preferred but, not required.

Job.JobDescription:
The Middle School Soccer Coach - Assistant position at Risdon Middle School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Middle School Soccer Coach - Assistant prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Risdon Middle School, the Middle School Soccer Coach - Assistant works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Middle School Soccer Coach - Assistant encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Middle School Soccer Coach - Assistant at Risdon Middle School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobTitle: Middle School Boys Basketball Head Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Middle School Boys Basketball Head Coach at Risdon Middle School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Middle School Boys Basketball Head Coach are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Risdon Middle School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Middle School Boys Basketball Head Coach recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Middle School Boys Basketball Head Coach collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Middle School Boys Basketball Head Coach maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Risdon Middle School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

The Head Coach - Boys Tennis at Central Valley High School is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Head Coach - Boys Tennis manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Central Valley High School, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Head Coach - Boys Tennis demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Head Coach - Boys Tennis follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Head Coach - Boys Tennis at Central Valley High School allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Purpose of Position:
The Girls' Swim Coach will oversee the West Girls' Swim Program and instruct the varsity high school swim team. They are responsible for helping each student-athlete gain success by reaching their full potential in the classroom and in the pool.
Supervisory Responsibilities:
Supervise the Girls Swim program coaching staff including Assistant/JV/Freshman coaches.
Essential Duties and Responsibilities:
Oversee training of swimmers in conjunction with the other coaches. Develop training plans for swimmers in conjunction with the other coaches. Assist in overseeing the running of specific events as needed at home meets as directed by the Director of Athletics. Contribute to match line-up planning with other coaches. Attend and coach at all practices. Attend and coach at all meets. Assist other coaches in monitoring team members' practice attendance, school attendance, meet attendance and grades Assist other coaches in enforcing team policies. Responsible for providing student-athletes feedback about their performance related to their disposition, behavior and team skills. Manage program budget organize fundraising efforts for the swim program Coordinate competition and practice schedules with the Director of Athletics and Operations. Coordinate off-season training for the swim program Successful completion of the required WIAA Rules Exam for swim by the 2027 fall sports season.
Qualifications:
Competitive playing experience in swim at the high school level. Previous coaching experience with preference to coaches with prior successful experience as varsity head swim coach. Demonstrated knowledge of a wide range of contemporary swim systems. Commitment to year-around personnel skill enhancement and program improvement. Demonstrated ability to provide positive motivation and development of student-athletes including year-around monitoring of conduct and academic performance. Demonstrated ability to maintain open communication with coaching staff, student-athletes, parents and age group swim coaches. Ability to integrate the swim program into the total school experience of the student-athlete. Preferred: Valid teaching license Preferred: College playing/coaching experience Preferred: Demonstrated ability to successfully implement swim systems in a high school setting
Length of Work:
WIAA 2027 Fall Sports Season
Working Conditions:
Will be expected to work in evenings and weekends. Will also be expected to work in various outdoor weather conditions.
Physical Requirements:
The job will require you to stand for extended periods of time, while coaching at practices and games.

Purpose of Position:
The Girls' Golf Coach will oversee the West Girls' Golf Program and instruct the varsity high school golf team. They are responsible for helping each student-athlete gain success by reaching their full potential in the classroom and on the course.
Supervisory Responsibilities:
Supervise the golf program coaching staff including Assistant/JV/Freshman coaches.
Essential Duties and Responsibilities:
Oversee training of golfers in conjunction with the other coaches. Develop training plans for golfers in conjunction with the other coaches. Assist in overseeing the running of specific events as needed at home meets as directed by the Director of Athletics. Contribute to match line-up planning with other coaches. Attend and coach at all practices. Attend and coach at all meets. Assist other coaches in monitoring team members' practice attendance, school attendance, meet attendance and grades Assist other coaches in enforcing team policies. Responsible for providing student-athletes feedback about their performance related to their disposition, behavior and team skills. Manage program budget organize fundraising efforts for the golf program Coordinate competition and practice schedules with the Director of Athletics and Operations. Coordinate off-season training for the golf program Successful completion of the required WIAA Rules Exam for golf by the 2027 fall sports season.
Qualifications:
Competitive playing experience in golf at the high school level. Previous coaching experience with preference to coaches with prior successful experience as varsity head golf coach. Demonstrated knowledge of a wide range of contemporary golf systems. Commitment to year-around personnel skill enhancement and program improvement. Demonstrated ability to provide positive motivation and development of student-athletes including year-around monitoring of conduct and academic performance. Demonstrated ability to maintain open communication with coaching staff, student-athletes, parents and age group golf coaches. Demonstrated knowledge about instructional progressions of golf techniques. Demonstrated ability to analyze opponent tendencies and to design responsive strategies. Current certification in first aid, with preference for course work in sports-medicine, injury prevention, rehabilitation and cooperation with team or family physicians. Current certification or must obtain within one month of employment and maintain CPR/AED certification from a national certifying organization. Skill in budgeting and supplemental fundraising. Skill in long-range planning for enhancement and maintenance of equipment inventories. Ability to coordinate all levels of competition within the golf program. Demonstrated ability to work with and coach a diverse population. Successful completion of an approved coach's education course (ASEP) or the ability to complete the course prior to the second season of coaching if no teaching license. Evidence the candidate is knowledgeable of WIAA eligibility standards and is willing to reinforce good sportsmanship and compliance with athletic codes among team members and members of the golf coaching staff. Ability to integrate the golf program into the total school experience of the student-athlete.
Preferred: Valid teaching license Preferred: College playing/coaching experience Preferred: Demonstrated ability to successfully implement golf systems in a high school setting
Length of Work:
WIAA 2027 Fall Sports Season
Working Conditions:
Will be expected to work in evenings and weekends. Will also be expected to work in various outdoor weather conditions.
Physical Requirements:
The job will require you to stand for extended periods of time, while coaching at practices and games.

Purpose of Position:
The Girls' Swim and Dive Head Coach is responsible for the overall operation of the La Follette Girls Swim and Dive Program. Responsibilities include providing instruction and coaching to student-athletes in the fundamentals of swim and dive and providing guidance to help each student-athlete reach the highest potential in the classroom and in the pool.
Supervisory Responsibilities:
Supervise the swim and dive program coaching staff including Assistant/JV/Freshman/Dive coaches.
Essential Duties and Responsibilities:
Oversee training of swimmers in conjunction with the other coaches. Develop training plans for swimmers in conjunction with the other coaches. Assist in overseeing the running of specific events as needed at home meets as directed by the Director of Athletics. Contribute to meet line-up planning with other coaches. Attend and coach at all practices. Attend and coach at all meets. Assist other coaches in monitoring team members' practice attendance, school attendance, meet attendance and grades Assist other coaches in enforcing team policies. Responsible for providing student-athletes feedback about their performance related to their disposition, behavior and team skills. Manage program budget organize fundraising efforts for the swim program Coordinate competition and practice schedules with the Director of Athletics and Operations. Coordinate off-season training and conditioning for the swim program Successful completion of the required WIAA Rules Exam for swim by the 2021-22 Fall Sports season.
Qualifications:
Knowledge of instructional techniques for competitive swimming.. Current certification or must obtain within one month of employment and maintain CPR/AED certification from a national certifying organization. If no teaching license, successful completion of an approved coach's education course (ASEP) or the ability to complete the course prior to the second season of coaching. Demonstrated ability to successfully coach in a diverse population. Ability to initiate and maintain open communication with staff, student athletes, and parents/guardians. Competitive experience in swimming at the high school level. Previous coaching experience with a preference for those with prior swim experience. Demonstrated knowledge of, and ability to design and implement a developmentally appropriate program for student-athletes in swimming. Evidence of knowledge of WIAA eligibility standards and willingness to reinforce good sportsmanship and compliance with athletic codes from members of the La Follette Swim team. Demonstrated ability to plan, organize, and supervise athletic teams with respect to schedules, equipment, student eligibility, and safety. Preferred: Valid teaching license Preferred: Lifeguard Certified Preferred: College playing/coaching experience Preferred: Demonstrated ability to successfully implement swimming systems in a high school setting
Length of Work:
WIAA 2026 Fall Sports Season
Working Conditions:
Will be expected to work in evenings and weekends.
Physical Requirements:
The job will require you to stand for extended periods of time, while coaching at practices and games.

Purpose of Position:
The Head Girls' Volleyball Coach will oversee the entire Memorial Girls' Volleyball Program and instruct the varsity high school volleyball team. They are responsible for helping each student-athlete gain success by reaching their full potential in the classroom and on the court.
Supervisory Responsibilities:
Supervise the volleyball program coaching staff, including JV/JV2 coaches.
Essential Duties and Responsibilities:
Oversee the training of volleyball players in all positions in conjunction with the other coaches. Develop training plans for volleyball players in conjunction with the other coaches. Assist in overseeing the running of specific events as needed at home games, as directed by the Director of Athletics and Operations. Contribute to game line-up planning with other coaches. Attend and coach at all practices. Attend and coach at all matches. Assist other coaches in monitoring team members' practice attendance, school attendance, match attendance and grades Assist other coaches in enforcing team policies. Responsible for providing student-athletes feedback about their performance related to their disposition, behavior and team skills. Manage program budget organize fundraising efforts for the volleyball program Coordinate competition and practice schedules with the Director of Athletics and Operations. Coordinate off-season training and conditioning for the volleyball program Successful completion of the required WIAA Rules Exam for volleyball by the 2021-22 Fall Sports season.
Qualifications:
Knowledge of instructional techniques for competitive volleyball. Current certification or must obtain within one month of employment and maintain CPR/AED certification from a national certifying organization. If no teaching license, successful completion of an approved coach's education course (ASEP) or the ability to complete the course prior to the second season of coaching. Demonstrated ability to successfully coach in a diverse population. Ability to initiate and maintain open communication with staff, student athletes, and parents/guardians. Competitive experience in volleyball at the high school level. Previous coaching experience with a preference for those with prior volleyball experience. Demonstrated knowledge of, and ability to design and implement a developmentally appropriate program for student-athletes in volleyball. Evidence of knowledge of WIAA eligibility standards and willingness to reinforce good sportsmanship and compliance with athletic codes from members of the Memorial Volleyball team. Demonstrated ability to plan, organize, and supervise athletic teams with respect to schedules, equipment, student eligibility, and safety. Preferred: Valid teaching license Preferred: College playing/coaching experience Preferred: Demonstrated ability to successfully implement volleyball systems in a high school setting
Length of Work:
WIAA 2026 Fall Sports Season with optional work activities in Spring 2026
Working Conditions:
Will be expected to work in evenings and weekends. In Season: 4:00 pm - 8:00 pm Monday - Friday, Saturday 8:00 am - 12:00 pm (sometimes longer for invites) Out of season: 25 hours a month
Physical Requirements:
The job will require you to stand for extended periods of time, while coaching at practices and games.

Job.CompanyDescription: Sch. Dist. of Waukesha coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The Coach - Assistant Baseball - North role at Waukesha North High School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Coach - Assistant Baseball - North is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Waukesha North High School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Coach - Assistant Baseball - North sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Waukesha North High School, the Coach - Assistant Baseball - North is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Coach - Assistant Baseball - North at Waukesha North High School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.CompanyDescription: Sch. Dist. of Waukesha coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The Coach - Assistant Softball - North role at Waukesha North High School emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Coach - Assistant Softball - North coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Waukesha North High School, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Coach - Assistant Softball - North reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Waukesha North High School at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Coach - Assistant Softball - North may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Coach - Assistant Softball - North monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Coach - Assistant Softball - North must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Waukesha North High School.
Job.CompanyDescription: Sch. Dist. of Waukesha coaching jobs

The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Assistant Baseball Coach at Memorial High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.
Job.CompanyDescription: Eau Claire Area S.D. coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Boys Golf Coach role at Memorial High School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Assistant Boys Golf Coach is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Memorial High School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Assistant Boys Golf Coach listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Assistant Boys Golf Coach encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Assistant Boys Golf Coach follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Memorial High School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Assistant Boys Golf Coach at Memorial High School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.
Job.CompanyDescription: Eau Claire Area S.D. coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Boys Tennis Coach at Memorial High School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Assistant Boys Tennis Coach are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Memorial High School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Assistant Boys Tennis Coach recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Assistant Boys Tennis Coach collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Assistant Boys Tennis Coach maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Memorial High School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.
Job.CompanyDescription: Eau Claire Area S.D. coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Girls Soccer Coach at Memorial High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Assistant Girls Soccer Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Memorial High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Assistant Girls Soccer Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Assistant Girls Soccer Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Assistant Girls Soccer Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Memorial High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Wrestling Coach - Bay View Middle School
Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Wrestling Coach - Bay View Middle School role at Tina Nowak is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Assistant Wrestling Coach - Bay View Middle School is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Tina Nowak, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Assistant Wrestling Coach - Bay View Middle School sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Tina Nowak, the Assistant Wrestling Coach - Bay View Middle School is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Assistant Wrestling Coach - Bay View Middle School at Tina Nowak is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.
Job.Experience: Previous coaching experience preferred
Job.Benefits: This position is not eligible for health or dental benefits based on ACA regulations.

Job.JobTitle: Strength and Conditioning Coach - Assistant Coach - Appleton East High School - 25/26 SY
Job.JobDescription:
The Appleton Area School District has a position available at Appleton East High School.
Description: Assistant Strength and Conditioning Coach
Supervisor: Activities Director
General Job Description: The Assistant Strength and Conditioning Coach works with the Head Strength and Conditioning Coach and is responsible for establishing and maintaining a strength and conditioning program for all sports, with the three major goals of improving athletic performance, mitigating athletic injuries, and teaching lifelong fitness and movement skills. The Strength and Conditioning Coach devises training plans according to sound scientific principles, supervises training sessions, evaluates athletes, and maintains athlete records. The Strength and Conditioning Coach meets regularly with sport coaches to determine what the athletes need to work on. If working with an injured athlete engaged in rehabilitation, the Strength and Conditioning Coach will consult with the sports medicine or licensed athletic training staff. The Strength and Conditioning Coach is responsible for maintaining the strength and conditioning facility, and for establishing policies, plans, and procedures for the safe and professional operation of the facility.
Essential Duties and Responsibilities 1. Design and implement strength training and conditioning programs in-season, off-season, and pre-season for all school-sanctioned male and female athletic programs in a manner that reflects research-driven practices. 2. Work in cooperation with the sports medicine or athletic training staff in the rehabilitation and strengthening of injured athletes. 3. Facilitate a collaborative relationship among sport coaches, sports medicine, and the strength and conditioning staff. 4. Design and implement policies and procedures for the strength and conditioning program in accordance with the NSCA Strength and Conditioning Professional Standards and Guidelines. 5. Develop systems for tracking athlete attendance and athlete progress in conjunction with the sport coaches. 6. Conduct an annual needs-analysis for each sport team in conjunction with the sport coach and the team’s athletic trainer at the conclusion of each sport season. 7. Annually conduct and review a departmental risk management plan. 8. Complete an annual budgetary proposal for the program that includes routine maintenance, purchase of new equipment, and staffing needs. 9. Determine and reinforce expectations for athlete conduct that mirror the school’s expectations for curricula and extra-curricular activities, as stated in the school’s Student Code of Conduct.
Peripheral Duties and Responsibilities 1. Design and assist curricular strength and conditioning classes, as needed. 2. Other duties as assigned. 3. Adhere to hourly allocations dedicated to strength and conditioning responsibilities.
Qualifications

Title: Assistant Coach Minimum Qualifications: Teacher certification as required by the state or Certification from WVSSAC Coaches Workshop. Immediate Supervisor(s): Principal, Athletic Director, Head Coach Supervises: Students RESPONSIBILITIES: PERFORMANCE STANDARDS: The following performance standards relate to the responsibilities listed below: 1. Leadership and support in area of responsibility: * Demonstrate knowledge of rules and regulations regarding his/her sport as presented in the WVSSAC Handbook * Assist head coach in proper registration of all athletes * Assist head coach in systematic issuance of equipment * Assist head coach in providing accurate information needed to compile eligibility lists and other reports * Inform his/her team of all rules and regulations, with specific emphasis on the Athletic Code of Conduct, and other athletic department policies * Be responsible for the actions and conduct of his/her team whenever they are under his/her jurisdiction * Emphasize safety precautions to control injury * Submit reports as required by the head coach and athletic director * Publicly support the philosophy and coaching techniques of the head coach * Carry out assigned duties and activities designated by the head coach 2. Establishing and implementing an improvement process for area of responsibility: * Exhibit knowledge of all rules and rule changes * Promote a good sportsmanship program * Apply discipline in a firm and positive manner 3. Establishing good public and employee relations in an area of responsibility: * Support the head coach in developing a positive image for his/her sport * Assist in recommending athletes for awards 4. Maintaining and upgrading his/her professional skills: * Accept and use new rules and regulations regarding his/her sport. * Attend the WVSSAC rules clinic. * Maintain and upgrade professional skills by involvement in the following: staff development, reading professional articles, advanced degrees, research and professional associations. All assistant coaches are answerable to the head coach and are expected to carry out the wishes and responsibilities set forth by the head coach. Reference here is made to such areas as systems of offense and defense, coaching techniques, scouting for the head coach, and other areas as assigned by the head coach and athletic director.

Position Type: Athletics/Activities/Athletic Trainer
Date Posted: 2/2/2026
Location: Central Office
Date Available: 2026-2027 School Year
Athletic Trainer Sweetwater School District #2
Position Summary The Athletic Trainer is a full-time health care professional responsible for providing comprehensive athletic training services to student-athletes across the district. This position focuses on injury prevention, evaluation, treatment, rehabilitation, and emergency care for interscholastic athletic programs. The Athletic Trainer works collaboratively with the Athletic Director, coaches, school administrators, nurses, physicians, and families to ensure the health, safety, and well-being of student-athletes in compliance with Wyoming law, Wyoming High School Activities Association (WHSAA) regulations, and school district policies. Reports To Athletic Director and/or District Administrator (as designated) Employment Status 189 Day Contract This position includes Benefits: Insurance, Retirement, and Paid Leave Time. Starting Salary: **Based on SWCSD2 Certified 185 Day Salary Schedule + an additional 4 Days (189 Days). Years of Experience and Educational Degree Level may also be considered
Essential Duties and Responsibilities Athletic Health Care & Injury Management • Provide daily, on-site athletic training services for district athletic programs, including practices, competitions, and events. • Prevent, recognize, evaluate, treat, and rehabilitate athletic injuries and medical conditions. • Develop and implement injury prevention programs and conditioning strategies appropriate for adolescent athletes. • Provide immediate care and emergency response for athletic-related injuries and medical emergencies. • Implement and oversee concussion management protocols in accordance with Wyoming state law, WHSAA guidelines, and district procedures. • Determine return-to-play readiness in collaboration with licensed physicians and ensure required medical clearances are obtained. Medical Coordination & Communication • Communicate effectively with student-athletes, parents/guardians, coaches, school nurses, administrators, and healthcare providers. • Coordinate referrals to physicians or other medical professionals as needed. • Assist with pre-participation physical examinations and medical screenings. • Maintain strict confidentiality of student medical records in compliance with FERPA, HIPAA, and district policies. Program Management & Compliance • Maintain accurate, timely, and confidential medical records, injury reports, and treatment documentation. • Ensure compliance with district policies, Wyoming statutes, WHSAA rules, and Board of Certification (BOC) standards. • Maintain and inventory athletic training facilities, equipment, and medical supplies to ensure a safe and effective environment. • Develop, implement, and regularly review Emergency Action Plans (EAPs) for all athletic venues. • Participate in professional development and maintain required licensure, certification, and continuing education requirements. Collaboration, Education & District Support • Provide education and training to coaches and staff on injury prevention, first aid, CPR/AED use, concussion awareness, and sports safety. • Support district wellness initiatives and promote safe participation in athletics. • Serve as a health and safety resource for the athletic department and district administration. • Assist with district athletic planning as it relates to student health and risk management. Required Qualifications • Bachelor's or Master's degree in Athletic Training • Current certification/licensure requirements as required by the State of Wyoming • Wyoming Athletic Trainer Certification required: https://athletictraining.wyo.gov/home • Knowledge of adolescent development and sports-related injuries. • Ability to work a flexible schedule, including evenings, weekends, and school holidays, as required by athletic schedules. Preferred Qualifications • Experience working in a secondary school or public school district setting. • Knowledge of WHSAA rules and interscholastic athletics. • Strong organizational, communication, and collaboration skills. Physical Demands • Ability to stand, walk, run, kneel, and bend for extended periods. • Ability to lift and carry equipment and supplies weighing up to 50 pounds. • Ability to respond quickly and effectively in emergency situations. Work Environment • Work is performed in indoor and outdoor athletic facilities and may involve exposure to varying weather conditions. • Potential exposure to bodily fluids and injuries common in athletic environments.
FLSA Status: Exempt
Job.Benefits: Insurance, Retirement, and Paid Leave Time

Job.JobTitle: Coach - GOHS Boys Soccer Head Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Coach - GOHS Boys Soccer Head Coach at Great Oak High School is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Coach - GOHS Boys Soccer Head Coach manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Great Oak High School, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Coach - GOHS Boys Soccer Head Coach demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. The District Office hosts twenty-three district level departments that serve the school sites. School sites feature many facility upgrades with vibrant libraries due to the community support of the Measure E bond. With 23 National Merit Scholars in 2021 and a total of 56 California Distinguished Schools/Gold Ribbon Awards, FUSD's mission is to provide equitable opportunities to Educate, Challenge and Inspire students of all ages, talents and ability levels, while striving to prepare each with the skills required to adapt and succeed in an ever-changing world. Job.JobTitle: Coach | Water Polo Men's JV HEAD - Monte Vista High
Job.JobDescription:
The Coach | Water Polo Men's JV HEAD - Monte Vista High position at Andy Popper is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Coach | Water Polo Men's JV HEAD - Monte Vista High works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Coach | Water Polo Men's JV HEAD - Monte Vista High at Andy Popper sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Andy Popper, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Coach | Water Polo Men's JV HEAD - Monte Vista High encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Coach | Water Polo Men's JV HEAD - Monte Vista High is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Coach | Water Polo Men's JV HEAD - Monte Vista High position at Andy Popper is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Department Description: As part of the University of San Diego, a Roman Catholic University, the Department of Intercollegiate Athletics is committed to advancing academic and athletic excellence and enhancing students' lives while promoting the University of San Diego.
University Description: The University of San Diego, an engaged and contemporary ... [I will manually combine the full text from my observations] ... This position is responsible for helping meet the fundraising objectives of the USD Department of Intercollegiate Athletics. Under the supervision of the Senior Associate Director of Athletics for Development, the Director /Assistant Athletic Director of Development for the Torero Athletic Fund (TAF) is a frontline fundraiser and team leader responsible for driving philanthropic support for USD Athletics through annual fund growth, major gifts, and exceptional stewardship. The Assistant Athletic Director owns the annual fund strategy for TAF, manages a dynamic portfolio of prospects (leadership annual and major gift), and partners closely with coaches, Athletics leadership, and Advancement colleagues to deliver a best-in-class donor experience. The role also oversees signature stewardship and engagement events that deepen donor loyalty and lifetime value.
Duties and Responsibilities: Annual Fund Leadership & Strategy: Develop and execute the annual fundraising plan for TAF, including revenue, membership growth, and retention targets across giving levels. ... [including all sections down to:] ... Special Conditions of Employment: Athletics Development is a complex division with various responsibilities to the university-at-large, various institutional constituencies, the president, senior administrative staff, and the Board of Trustees. This employee's personality and temperament are just as important as any particular skill. This employee must have the ability to maintain a professional demeanor, utilize tact and discretion, and maintain the strictest confidentiality. Background check: Successful completion of a pre-employment background check. Degree Verification Requirement: Persons offered employment in this position will be required to provide official education transcripts for degree verification purposes. Minimum Qualifications: Bachelor's degree required. Director: Three years+ of related experience required. Assistant Athletic Director: Four years+ of fundraising or related experience required. Excellent written and oral communication skills, as well as exceptional critical listening and thinking skills. Command of the English language, including AP writing style and standard grammar, spelling, punctuation, syntax, and proofreading skill. Strong teamwork and leadership skills. Experience in managing teams at all levels across an organization. Preferred Qualifications: Master’s degree preferred. Prior experience working in Intercollegiate Athletics, specifically Division I, strongly preferred. Experience with database management systems, such as Blackbaud CRM and/or Reeher, preferred. Experience with other technological tools, including Google suite, Microsoft Office, Tableau and other data visualization tools preferred. Job.JobTitle: Head Girls Water Polo Coach @ College Park High School #3925
Job.JobDescription: STANDARDS FOR ATHLETIC TEAM COACHES The following standards are minimum qualifications for applicants to athletic team coach positions in the Mt. Diablo Unified School District. Knowledge, training, and demonstrated competency in the following areas are required to qualify for any athletic coach position in the District. 1. Knowledge and Competencies: Knowledge and competency related to care and prevention of athletic injuries, basic first aid and emergency procedures which may be evidenced by one or more of the following: Completion of a college-level course in the care and prevention of athletic injuries and possession of a valid cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) card. A valid sports injury certificated or first aid card, and a valid cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) card. 2. Coaching Techniques: The coach shall be knowledgeable in coaching theory and techniques in the sport or game being coached as evidenced by one or more of the following: Completion of a college course in coaching theory and techniques of the specific sport. Completion of in-service programs arranged by a school district or county office of education in the specific sport. Prior services as a head or assistant athletic coach in the specific sport. Prior participation in organized competitive athletics at high school level or above in the sport being coached. 3. Rules and Regulations in the Athletic Activity Being Coached including: Training and knowledge of the rules and regulations in the athletic activity being coached and demonstrated ability to communicate those rules and regulations in an e?ective, respectful manner which instills teamwork, commitment and discipline. The coach shall have knowledge of the rules and regulations of the North Coast Section pertaining to the sport or game being coached, the league rules, and regulations of the California Interscholastic Federation. Additional Competencies for Non-certificated Personnel In addition to the competencies listed above, it shall be determined that a non-certificated person employed as a temporary athletic coach: Has not been convicted of any offense referred to in Education Code 44010, 44011 or 44424, or any offense involving moral turpitude or evidencing unfitness to associate with children. Is free from tuberculosis and any other contagious disease that would prohibit certi?cated teachers from teaching, as verified by a written statement, renewable every four years, from a licensed physician or other person approved by the district 5. Code of Ethical Conduct: Applicants for athletic team coach positions shall be expected to demonstrate knowledge, training and competency to insure compliance with the following Code of Ethical Conduct. In addition, all athletic team coaches providing supervisory or instructional services in interscholastic athletic programs shall abide by the Code of Ethical Conduct. Show respect for players, o?cials, other coaches and parents Respect the integrity and judgment of game o?cials. Establish and model fair play, sportsmanship and proper conduct. Establish player safety and welfare as the highest priority. Provide an environment that instills teamwork, commitment and discipline. Provide leadership which promotes a positive experience for the student athlete. Provide proper supervision of students at all times. Use discretion when providing constructive criticism and when reprimanding players. Maintain consistency in requiring all players to adhere to the established rules and standards of the game. Properly instruct players in the safe use of equipment. Avoid exerting undue influence on a student's decision to enroll in an athletic program at any public or private postsecondary educational institution. Avoid exerting undue influence on students to take lighter academic course(s) in order to be eligible to participate in athletics. Avoid suggesting, providing or encouraging any athlete to use non-prescriptive drugs, anabolic steroids or any substance to increase physical development or performance that is not approved by the Food and Drug Administration, U.S. Surgeon General or the American Medical Association. Avoid recruitment of athletes from other schools. Work e?ectively with booster groups. Work e?ectively with school administration. Position Type: Part-Time Job Categories: Athletics & Activities > Coaching Job Requirements: Citizenship, residency or work visa required
